title: paul routledge urgent cross party
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Urgent cross-party agreement needed to sort out welfare threatThe Tories have done nothing to aid a system in crisis - so when will their promises come into place ShareByPaul Routledge:,  MAY NewsopinionTheresa May made some more big promises this week "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The biggest casualty of Brexit has nothing to do with Brussels.It is the scandal of millions of old, vulnerable and young people deprived of adequate social care. Since the Tories came to power, £billion has been cut from budgets. They pledge reform for a system they admit is in crisis, but they’ve done nothing.A Government Green Paper just to talk about change is years late. Theresa May promised this week: “I will be bringing proposals”, but when, Prime Minister, when  When will you stop hiding behind Brexit  Damian Green, her short-lived deputy PM, suggests a £.billion scheme to give everyone free basic care where they live or in a home. It would be paid for by an extra  per cent on national insurance for the over-s or in part by a raid on winter fuel ­allowances for better-off pensioners.Labour promises to spend an extra £billion a year to improve support for older people and those with dementia. Half would go on , care ­packages, with £million for training staff and allowances for full-time family carers.   There is merit in both ideas, but the imperative is to stop the talking and bloody well get on with it. This challenge is bigger than tribal politics. We need cross-party ­agreement at Westminster to sort out the gravest threat to the welfare state since its inception. Meanwhile, care home operator Four Seasons, coping with , residents, went bust this week, blaming rising costs and massive cuts in council spending. And MPs warn that ­children’s services are “at breaking point” because of budget cuts of % since . The entire system is spiralling out of control. The Government needs no go-ahead from Brussels to properly fund social care. Ministerial obsession with Brexit is merely a fig leaf to cover their criminal laziness, incompetence and “don’t care” attitude to those most in need. Labour has ­championed a National Care Service, funded and run like the NHS. That’s where politicians should be looking.

title: labour hail trafford victory amid
story: NewsLabour hail Trafford victory amid tough local election results for the partyUntil last year the council was the only blue local authority in Greater Manchester in a sea of redShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsJeremy Corbyn visited Greater Manchester on the campaign trail "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour has hailed success in Trafford after the party took back full control of the council for the first time since  - ending a long run of Tory rule. Until last year it was the only blue local authority in Greater Manchester in a sea of red. But on Thursday night Tories lost all nine of the seats they were defending, confirming their worst fears during the campaign. Labour won all six of the seats it was targeting, while the Greens also took one from the Tories in Altrincham and the Lib Dems one in Timperley. It is the result of a long term campaign in the area but was also hailed as a success from the national party during a tough night. It was especially signicant as Labour had some relatively tough results in some of its northern heartlands.  it will also be cause for celebration: a big northern Tory council scalp on a night where the party appears to be getting a bit of a kicking - relatively speaking - in some existing Labour-controlled northern areas. Hailing the result in Trafford, Shadow Women and Equalities Minister Dawn Butler said Weaposre really pleased that we have won Trafford.    Iaposm sure we will add to that as the evening wears on. Labour lost nine seats in Sunderland, seven seats in both Barnsley and Bolton and five seats in South Tyneside. Labour Party spokesperson: “Taking Trafford Council is a great result for Labour and has completely extinguished Tory blue from the Greater Manchester map. Voters have seen over the last year what a dference Labour can make and have given the Labour councillors a thumping vote of confidence.”

title: local election results explained tories
story: NewsLocal election results explained: Tories lose HUNDREDS of seats but Labour struggleThe Tories have lost hundreds of seats in a bruising local elections night - yet the spoils havent been seized by Labour. Heres how the results unfolded overnight and what they meanShareByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY News"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVoters have dealt a blow to both main parties in a bruising night of local elections. The Tories lost hundreds of seats as local councillors were punished for a Parliament in chaos over Brexit. But Labour failed to seize the spoils from the Toriesapos loss - with huge gains instead going to the Lib Dems, who boasted of their best night for  years. By am, with  out of  councils declared, the Tories had lost  seats overall. And despite fighting a beleaguered party of government that did well last time, Labour also lost .The Lib Dems had gained  seats while the Greens gained  and Independents gained .     More than , seats were up for election across England outside London. Local factors will always be partly to blame, and thereaposs a mixed picture. Labour did well in some areas like Trafford while losing control of symbolic northern Hartlepool, Bolsover and Wirral. Thereaposs also much more to come, with half of councils only declaring during Friday afternoon. But some MPs were quick to blame the partyaposs middle-ground approach to Brexit.Labour MP Jess Phillips fumed: I canapost help but think that the public like a clear message eventhey donapost always agree with it. . Tories are losing hundreds of seats - and thataposs VERY bad news for them in the EU elections  Itaposs been a bruising night for the Conservative Party as they lost more than  seats. The Tories lost control of heartland working-class Home Counties councils including Basildon, Southend-on-Sea and Folkestone  Hythe. Commuter-belt St Albans and Welwyn Hatfield also fell out of blue control. They also lost control of Broxtowe - home to the Remainer MP Anna Soubry - amid Labour gains. None of that bodes well for the EU elections on May , where the Tories will be up against Nigel Farageaposs Brexit Party . . It may not be bad enough to force out Theresa May  The damage limitation spin machine is in its full  RPM cycle as Tories point out the losses werenapost as bad as expected. And so far thataposs true, as there were predictions the Tories would lose  to , seats.Tory MPs looking for a glimmer of hope are right about another thing too - the Conservatives made good gains the last time these seats were up for election in .And as todayaposs elections were mainly in Tory strongholds , the Tories had the most to lose. Tory Brexiteer Priti Patel said people had made clear Theresa May was part of the problem and there needs to be a change of leadership. And yes, there is a grassroots movement against her. But others will move to paint the result as not a disaster and keep the PM in office. Brexit Minister James Cleverly said: If it was  [losses] rather than , I would be happy with that. And in reality, with the EU elections in three weeks looking like they could go much worse for the Tories, MPs may wait until then to move against Mrs May. Conservative MP for East Surrey Sam Gyimah said the partyaposs loss of control in Tandridge, Surrey, was disappointing but not surprising, citing two non-Brexit-related issues. And while the Conservative party suffered signicant losses across the country, Tory MP Eddie Hughes had cause to celebrate as his party gained Walsall North from no overall control. . Labour are NOT profiting from the Tory failure Labour have been in opposition for nine years but are not making the kind of gains you might expect. Jeremy Corbynaposs party had some big symbolic wins, finally seizing the once-blue Manchester island of Trafford back into red control. There were some southern gains too, such as six seats in Folkestone and Hythe. And Labour gained one seat in Peterborough - which is staging a crucial by-election on June  - as the Tories lost it to No Overall Control. But Labour also lost control of northern Bolsover, home to legendary Brexiteer Labour MP Dennis Skinner. The party failed to gain control of Midlands Brexit stomping ground Stoke-on-Trent. Hartlepool was lost from Labour control as was Wirral - where the Labour share of the vote was down %, according to the BBC. And an eye-watering nine seats were lost in northern Labour heartland - and Leave-voting area - Sunderland. Labour’s Dawn Butler has admitted Labour did not do as well as expected because MPs are “in a mess”. The shadow cabinet minister told Sky News: “We have to be honest, parliament is a mess at the moment, we’re not making much progress, so it does affect everybody in parliament.” She added: “These are very unusual times politically. Some have described it as being since World War  we haven’t seen this type of election Polling guru John Curtice said the Tories were being punished more heavily in the south of England, where Lib Dems often have a hold, than the Labour north. Clearly these elections were never going to be easy for us and there are still many results to come, said Labour MP Nia Grfith at am. . Yet Lib Dems have their aposbest results since apos - even in Brexit Country Lib Dems could not contain there glee after picking up a string of seats and gaining control of key areas - including Brexiteer Tory Jacob Rees-Moggaposs back yard. They also gained Winchester, North Norfolk and Cotswold. With predictions the Lib Dems could gain as many as  seats, MP Layla Moran claimed these are the best local election results for the party since  - in the aftermath of the Iraq War. MP Ed Davey claimed his party was having an awesome night thanks to voters rejecting Labour and the Conservatives, citing hard work rather than Brexit issues for their success. . The Green Party and Independents have done well too The Green Party and Independents had an excellent night as voters vent their protest against the main two parties, polling guru John Curtice said. The expert said it was one of the Greensapos best performances ever. It comes in the wake of the Extinction Rebellion protests, which have raised awareness of climate issues. But the rise of Independents and small parties also recognises an anger at the main, establishment parties. Independents gained  seats in Bolsover and gained North Kesteven council from the Tories. . The North South ide is real The same picture keeps being highlighted - Labour gains are best in the South, and Tory losses are worst in the South. Politics professor at Manchester University Rob Ford claimed the north saw a swing of % against the Tories and % against Labour. Yet in the Midlands there was no change for Labour, as opposed to a % drop for the Midlands. And in the South, Labour gained .%, as opposed to a .% Tory drop - with a whopping . point swing from the Conservatives to Jeremy Corbynaposs Party. . But furious Labour MPs are blaming Brexit for the struggle Remain-backing Labour MPs claim the party is struggling because it hasnapost come down firmly on one side over Brexit. The party is continuing to pursue its own Brexit plan, while keeping a second EU referendum as an option on the table in case needed, but not in all cases. Labour MP Jess Phillips reacted by saying her partyaposs position on Brexit had failed. Iaposm off to bed as have to be up at am to do the school run, she tweeted. My final word is that I think our position on Brexit has failed. Bravery is needed. If you combine kindness and effectiveness with a bit of grit most people will respect you even when they donapost always agree. Fellow Labour MP Wes Streeting said losses in Sunderland and Liverpool demonstrated that looking both ways on Brexit isnapost doing Labour any good.

Around  councils held crucial local elections just as the country is consumed by chaos over Brexit. Traditionally local elections do not always reflect national issues so well - so it will be hard to draw a single pattern or story from the results. But with the Tories defending more than half the , seats up for grabs, and a huge revolt in the Conservative grassroots over Brexit, a big story will be whether blue votes slip away. So are you, like us, sticking the kettle on and munching on hobnobs for a rough night of result-watching  Hooray! Look no further - here are the rough times you can expect each areaaposs result - with all the usual warnings that they could change dramatically.  How do I watch the results  We are covering the results right here at mirror politics from pm on Thursday  May right through to Friday evening. The latest state of the parties is below: Whoaposs voting and what for   Councillor elections are being held in  town, city, borough and county halls - occupying most of England outside London and Birmingham. Polls opened at am on Thursday  May and were due to close at pm. Some councils only have a third of seats up for grabs while some are putting up every single seat. In total  unitary councils,  metropolitan boroughs and  non-metropolitan districts are taking part. There are also elections for six directly-elected mayors - in Bedford, Copeland, Leicester, Mansfield, Middlesbrough and North of Tyne. Which party will aposwinapos   The Tories will technically win - get the most seats - because they currently hold more than half the , council seats up for grabs. Thataposs because this yearaposs elections are focused on more rural areas that are Tory strongholds. But that huge total also means the Tories have the most to lose from low turnout and voters frustrated by Brexit . And matters could be made worse by the fact that the last elections of this kind were in  - a high point for the Tories when they unexpectedly won the general election on the same day. Tory peer and pollster Robert Hayward has predicted the Tories could lose  seats while the Lib Dems pick up  and Labour claw back . More than half the councils up for grabsare Tory-controlled, according to the Local Government Information Unit. Labour is defending just , seats while Lib Dems hold , Independents hold  and  seats belong to smaller parties or community groups, according to Tory peer Robert Hayward . Labour controls  councils, while seven are in Lib Dem hands and  are under no overall control. Five are new councils.  Swindonwill be one of the first results and a big one to watch for Labour. If Labour do well the Tories could lose their overall control. Ashfieldwas Labour until a slew of defections last year to Independents and Tories. Will it tip back  Thanetwas once UKIPaposs stronghold and aposIndependent and UKIPapos are the second-largest grouping. Tories hold the administration and should gainBrexitaposs going well. Or the vote could go to anti-establishment parties. Lib Dems are tipped to make gains in  Bath and North East Somersetand  Wokingham- home to hard Brexiteer Tory MPs  Jacob Rees-Mogg  and John Redwood. Labour need a small change to seize control of  Trafford , which the Tories lost as their jewel in red Manchester, and  Calderdalewhich Labour hope to control for the first time since . But Tories are standing candidates in every seat in every metropolitan authority, so theyaposll put up a fight. Itaposs a tougher battle in neck-and-neck red-blue battlegrounds Crawley , Carlisleand  Brighton .  Dudleyhas a minority Labour administration but only on a kne-edge, and a small change could tip it back to the Tories.  Walsalland  Stoke-on-Trentare on a kne-edge the other way round, with only a small change needed for Labour to come out on top. Labour also only need a small boost in  Derbyto gain control from an unusual pairing of Tories, Lib Dems and UKIP, But Labour had big losses last year and itaposs one of  councils where UKIP are putting up a full slate of candidates. Labour only needs a little gain in  Redcar and Clevelandto get overall control. And the Tories need just one extra seat to gain control in  Scarboroughand  Teignbridge-  or two in  Thurrock .    Any signs of an anti-Brexit effect could come in  Stockport ,  a minority Labour council with a big Lib Dem contingent. And Tories appear worried about Theresa Mayaposs image in  Cheshire Eastand  Wirral ,  where you can find some standing under a aposlocal Conservativesapos ticket. Maidstoneis a Lib Dem-Tory battleground, with the yellows in power but the blues needing four gains to seize control. So is  Winchester ,  where the Lib Dems are just one seat behind the Tories, and  North Norfolkand  Portsmouth .    Some councils are narrowly held so could be thrown into no overall control with just a slight change. They include  Cannock Chase,  Three Riversand  South Somerset and  Mole Valley , Tandridge , Pendleand  Woking. And the Tories could lose overall control in  Hertfordshireor  Peterborough theyaposre having a bad night. Meanwhile some rock-solid councils will be worth watching. Tories are defending  of  seats in  Amber Valley ,  so this will be target practice for rivals. The Greens are hopeful in  Stratford-upon-Avonwhere theyaposre putting up a full slate of candidates. Leedshas  dferent political groups standing - the most of any area. But not everyone has to fight for survival.  seats are unopposed or guaranteed in  Fenland . Around half of councilsapos results are being counted overnight, with results expected from midnight. The other half will start being counted on Friday morning so results can be expected to pour in after lunch. story: NewsLocal elections: Woman, , whos voted all her le turned away for having no IDEXCLUSIVE: The -year-old woman left a polling station without casting her vote in Pendle, Lancashire, as part of a regional trial of anti-fraud checksShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe woman was turned away from a polling station in Pendle"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn -year-old woman has been turned away from todayaposs local elections for not having ID - despite voting in every election in her adult le. The pensioner attacked the “stupid” system after taking a taxi to her local polling station in Pendle, Lancashire, only to be told she couldn’t vote. She told the Mirror she brought a photograph of herself, rather than a photo ID, after she misunderstood the instructions. Pendle Borough Council ing officer Philip Mousdale told the Mirror he was very sorry to hear about the case and the last thing we want is people being unable to vote. It came as voters across  areas elected , councillors in todayaposs town hall elections - with polls closing at pm. Most voters can cast their ballot simply by giving their name. But  council areas - including Pendle - are piloting a controversial anti-fraud scheme that demands ID from voters before they can cast their ballot. The scheme is being rolled out by the Tory government at a cost of millions of pounds despite just eight allegations of in-person voter fraud last year. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn responded to our story by saying: The Conservatives are trying to rig our elections by making it harder for people to vote - itaposs voter suppression. These dangerous voter ID plans must be scrapped.    The Mirror knows the womanaposs identity but she asked to stay anonymous. She said: “I am nearly . And the officers that were on, they know me, but they weren’t allowed to let me vote. How stupid is that ” The pensioner claimed she had voted in every election since she came of age at  - even small local elections. But speaking just after lunchtime, she said she was not planning toto vote before polls closed today at pm. She said: “I can’t fly so I’ve no passport now. I can’t drive so I’ve no driving licence now.  “If I’d been in Craven they would have accepted my bankers’ card but because I’m in Pendle they don’t accept it.” The Cabinet Office and Pendle Council insisted a wide range of photo ID - not just driversapos licences or passports - could be used. The woman said she later went to a luncheon club with her husband, where another diner said they had torn up their ballot paper in protest. The woman - who declined to tell us how she would have voted - said: “I just think it’s not right. “We’ve lived all our lives in England and are having to take a photograph to confirm who we are.” It is thought the womanaposs husband did bring photo ID.    Pendle was one of two councils in todayaposs pilot where polling stations would only accept photo ID. The other was Woking. Either a photo ID or a polling card were acceptable in Mid Sussex, Watford and North West Leicestershire. And polling stations were able to accept either one piece of photo ID, or two pieces of non-photo ID, in Broxtowe, Craven, Derby, North Kesteven and Braintree. The -year-old womanaposs case was flagged to a local Labour Party office. Labour candidate Wayne Blackburn, , said it was by far the worst case he had seen. He told us at pm, when polls had been open for eight hours: I have heard of a couple more where people have been turned away. In one case someone was turned away and they categorically said they wouldnapost be ing.  A Pendle Borough Council official confirmed the womanaposs account of what happened was accurate. Pendle Borough Council ing officer Philip Mousdale told the Mirror: “The last thing we want is people being unable to vote so I’m very sorry to hear about this case. “We ran a far reaching communications campaign, which included writing to all households twice, to let residents know that photo ID would be needed to vote and how to apply for a Local Electoral Cardthey didn’t have any. “And the poll cards were another reminder of the need for photo ID listing what would be accepted.” Other anecdotal cases have been reported to the Mirror. And one voter, Jake Pitt, wrote on Twitter : Went to vote in Mid Sussex today which is trialing VoterID - had a polling card but was told I was not on the system,  mins later after presiding officer calls the database controller Iaposm finally able to vote. Chaotic. Have you been turned away today in one of the  trial areas for having no ID  Did youand vote later  Get in touch with us using this form or email webnews@mirror. Labouraposs Shadow Minister for Voter Engagement Cat Smith said: “It is unsurprising that reports are coming in of legitimate and honest voters being denied their right to vote because of these undemocratic and unpopular pilot schemes. “Time and time again Labour warned that Voter ID will make it harder for people to vote but this Government ploughed ahead with this dangerous policy. “Given that there is no evidence of widespread electoral fraud, one voter being turned away from the polling station is too many. “After today’s shambles, it’s clear that Voter ID has no place in our democracy and should be abandoned immediately.    Groups including Age UK, Liberty and the British Youth Council united in a joint warning over the voter ID checks as the polls opened today. Caroline Abrahams, Charity Director of Age UK, claimed ID checks “could inadvertently impede some older people from voting” as they are less likely to have photo ID. She added: “We understand that it is important to reduce the risks of electoral fraud but this could end up undermining the democracy they are designed to protect.” Darren Hughes, Chief Executive of the Electoral Reform Society , said: “These voter ID plans –rolled out nationally -  could pull up the drawbridge for millions of voters.” There were eight cases of alleged apospersonationaposlast year, down from  in ,  in ,  in  and  in .  Yet an ERS study last year claimed  people were turned away in the five previous trial areas for not having ID. Ministers spent £.m on the trial of ID checks in five areas last year, with voter ID checks expected to cost between £.m and £.mrolled out in a full general election, depending on the system used. Despite a challenge by campaigners, the High Court has ruled ID checks lawful. A Cabinet Office spokesperson said: Electoral fraud is an unacceptable crime that strikes at a core principle of our democracy - that everyone’s vote matters. Showing ID to vote is a reasonable way to stop this and is something people already do every day, when they pick up a parcel at the Post Office, claim their benefits, or take out a library book. Both last year’s pilots and the decades of experience of Northern Ireland show that voter ID does not have an adverse effect on election turnout or participation.

The street in Kingaposs Norton, Birmingham, appears rundown and aposdecayedapos.Empty buildings have been set on fire, stripped of lead and plastered in graffiti while the street is regularly fly-tipped with rubbish, paint and large tyres, Birmingham Live reports.A former resident said: Itaposs almost like a cowboy Western film with an ambush site in the canyon. People know not to go down there, itaposs dangerous. The street has become a magnet for anti-social behaviour and people have called it dangerous after a taxi driver was stabbed there. Most of the residents on the Avenue have been moved out as many of the buildings are to be torn down as part of a wider regeneration project by Birmingham City Council. The project has been rehousing tenants in the last two years.  But the authority has been criticised for leaving some residents, whose bungalows are to remain, isolated and vulnerable due to slow progress with the scheme. The council confirmed demolition was due to start next month, saying delays had been caused by having to acquire private properties and carrying out bat surveys.West Midlands Police  has declared the road, and others surrounding it, as a priority.Public safety concerns have heightened after an incident on Sunday, March , when a taxi driver was stabbed by two passengers who demanded money from him and then stole his car.  The -year-old man was taken to hospital with none le-threatening injuries after Kathleen Witheridge, , who lives in a bungalow on Gildas Avenue, flagged down police. She said: I had a knock on the door. I donapost open the door in the evenings but I looked through the spy hole and could see blood on the manaposs face. I opened it on the chain and he said aposcan you call the police Iaposve been stabbedapos. I opened the door and saw it wasnapost just his face, he was covered in blood, he had multiple stab wounds. It frightened the le out of me to be truthful. I couldnapost get the vision of the man out of my head. It was a few nights before I could sleep. It really upset me.  Describing everyday le on Gildas Avenue she added: Mostly itaposs just kids being idiots, knocking doors and running off. I try to keep myself to myself and donapost go out in the evenings. But it looks really horrible. Itaposs like a war zone with all of the rubbish and graffiti everywhere. I donapost feel comfortable here at the moment. Theyshould put boards or railings up around the buildings just to make us feel like something is moving forward. Nobody tells us anything.  Neighbours echoed the feeling. Mother-of-two Michelle Mulhall, aged , said: I think itaposs disgusting how the council have left residents. Itaposs bad down here. The buildings have just been boarded up and left. Nobody wants to come down here. Jane Cope, chairperson for the neighbouring Druids Heath and Monyhull Forum, is a former resident of the area and is worried for the safety of those who remain, including her friend Kathleen.  She said: The taxi driver was lured there to be attacked. Since then itaposs become a no-go zone. People know they are vulnerablethey go down there. You have also got these little alleyways leading off it where people can make a quick getaway. Itaposs almost like a cowboy Western film with an ambush site in the canyon. People know not to go down there, itaposs dangerous. Thereaposs just a complete lack of security. Thereaposs vulnerable people in those bungalows who are scared to open their doors. They have been left there with no support.  The forum is also concerned with the way the city council handles major estate regeneration, with their ward Druids Heath earmarked for similar redevelopment over the coming years. Ms Cope added: The residents have been in touch with the council to say whataposs happening and nobody is giving them answers. I appreciatethere are issues but keeping people in the dark doesnapost help, because it gives them no hope. If itaposs going to be some time before the buildings are taken down then they shouldnapost leave those people so scared and vulnerable. It could mean relocating them or upping security measures.  A council spokeswoman said: Gildas Avenue is part of the first phase of a broader six-year clearance programme which will help to regenerate the area. All council tenants have been rehoused however, there were a number of private properties which have been acquired from owners on a voluntary basis. Planning approval was granted [for demolition] subject to a number of conditions, one of which was that bat surveys had to be carried out to all properties. These can only be carried out once properties were vacant and are set to commence imminently and will take two weeks. Following this activity, demolition is intended for early June .  She added: This is a six-year regeneration programme and so as new information becomes available and our wider plans for the estate are developed, residents will be kept informed as to progress and time scales and given the opportunity for input and comment. Gildas Avenue is also on a weekly rota for collection, removal and safe disposal of any fly-tipping. The area is also part of the management regime meaning officers carry out an estate check to ensure the void premises are secure and where there is a breach, appropriate action is taken. The team works closely with the emergency services to identy and mitigate any risk. A force spokeswoman said: Officers are aware of anti-social behaviour, arson and criminal damage issues in the residential areas surrounding Arrow Walk Park, Kings Norton. The area is currently being treated as a priority and West Midlands Police is focusing resources and activities to prevent crime and potentially reduce overall crime levels in the wider locality. The area encompasses The Fold, Gildas Avenue, Sisefield Road and Greaves Square. She confirmed the stabbing incident was still being investigated adding: No arrests have been made but the taxi cab was recovered shortly after the incident and has been forensically examined. Investigators are also following up a number of other leads.Anyone with information on the incident should contact police on  or via live chat at  west-midlands.police.uk  quoting the crime reference BW L .

title: what living nuclear armed submarine
story: NewsWhat living on nuclear-armed submarine for three months is REALLY likeWe visited the HM Naval Base Clyde in Scotland - and you can forget all about your creature comfortsShareCommentsBySam Elliott:,  MAY NewsThe stark reality of working for three months under water "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn missions lasting three months, submariners in our nuclear-armed fleet have no TV, internet or radio, their only contact with home an occasional -word “familygram”. At sea, nine men must share a living space just eight feet square, their bunks stacked three high. But on HMS Vigilant, engineering technician David Thomson, , from Glasgow, said: “I don’t find it bad on board at all. You get used to it. “I have been working on here for three and a half years and it has been absolutely fine. “When you are underwater, it doesn’t make much of a dference – you just get on with your job.”    The Daily Mirror was visiting HM Naval Base Clyde, Faslane, in Scotland, to mark the th anniversary of the introduction of the at-sea nuclear weapons deterrent. Four Vanguard-class submarines – the Vanguard, Victorious, Vigilant and Vengeance – were introduced in  as part of the Trident programme. On missions, the  crew eat more than ,kgs of bacon, , sausages, , eggs, , chocolate bars, ,kgs of potatoes, , bread rolls and more than , tins of beans.    It is vital the subs’ locations are kept secret so potential attackers never know where a salvo might come from, and silence is maintained at all times. Metal clanging is a giveaway, so there is no slamming of hatches, unnecessary hammering of tools, no loud music. The crew must rely on a daily news sheet to tell them what is going on in the world.    Commodore Bob Anstey, Assistant Chief of Staff Submarines, said: “You can still keep abreast of the news and receive written messages from family. “People can get good news about the arrival of a new baby, but sometimes the captain has to avoid giving personnel bad news while at sea.” Technician David admits there are downsides: “It can take a while getting used to not having home comforts – like being able to read the Daily Mirror.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

All in one skip.The history of the shed goes back to its construction in  by Peter MacGregor of Oakbank, Ardrishaig, who ran a garage there for many years.Ardrishaig woman Nikki Thompson has been looking into the shed#s history for the Argyllshire Advertiser and discovered it appears to have always been used as a garage.Nikki said: #No-one can recall exact dates, however, ious businesses worked there.#At some point it had hand-operated petrol pumps outside # one pump up for a gallon and one pump down for another. It was then used by the Department of Agriculture Scotland for maintaining tractors.#Following that it was taken over by Archie Ferguson, haulier, who lived at the back of Ardrishaig, behind Loch Fyne Terrace.#Ronnie Gordon took it over as the Pier Garage in the s and worked there for  years. When he retired in  his son Kris took over the business before moving to adjacent canal premises last year.#The future for the empty site is not yet decided, but a spokesman for Scottish Canals told the Argyllshire Advertiser that it may host an art installation for a period, in a similar vein to other canal-side venues around Scotland.What are your memories of the tin garage Let us know by emailing editor@argyllshireadvertiser, by phone on   or via the Advertiser Facebook page.PICS:Before the machines move in. no_aArdGarageAnd so it begins. no_aArdGarageThe machine makes short work of the corrugated iron cladding. no_aArdGarageAfter a couple of hours, it#s all gone. no_aArdGarageThe new Pier Garage is situated directly across the road. _aArdGarageDemolition

title: local-authority-launches-pioneering-eco-friendly-car-hire-in-the-borders
story: A PIONEERING new motoring project has hit the road in the Scottish Borders.A fleet of brand-new, low emission Toyota Yaris hybrids have arrived in several Borders towns.And you can drive the eco-friendly vehicles for as little as pound. an hour or pound per day.The scheme is being delivered by Scottish Borders Council in partnership with E-Car Club.Councillor Simon Mountford told us: ldquoWe already have a successful partnership with E-Car Club to use Toyota Hybrids as pool cars for our staff."As a result of this we have seen more shared journeys by employees, a reduction in business mileage claims and lower emissions."This next stage, which allows members of the public to join a car club scheme, is hugely exciting."Vehicles are available to book across the Borders and I believe many of our local residents will take advantage of this when they need access to a car for a few hours or even a full day.The vehicles are specially adapted to include an RFID card access system, meaning the cars can be booked online or through the free E-Car Club mobile app.Bookings can be made for anyof time over one hour, and insurance is even included in the price.Patrick Cresswell, Managing Director at E-Car Club, commented: ldquoWe are delighted to give Borders residents the opportunity to integrate low emission vehicles into their everyday lives through E-Car which offers a self-service, low cost and low emission car club."Itrsquos a flexible solution for drivers who donrsquot want to commit to car ownership but need access to a car from time to time."We hope this scheme will encourage car owners to consider using the service as an alternative to vehicle ownership. And that should result in fewer cars on the road, and ultimately reducing emissions and congestion.The cars are parked in Peebles, Eyemouth, Duns, Kelso, Galashiels, Hawick and Newtown St Boswells, in allocated spaces prepared by Scottish Borders Council.As the vehicles double up as local authority pool cars they are only available in the evenings and overnight between pm and am from Monday to Wednesday.But they are for hire anytime from pm on Thursday through to am on Monday.As the vehicles are hybrid, they come with two power sources - a petrol engine and an electric motor.The majority of Toyota Hybrids are self-charging which means that every moment you are driving, your battery is charging even when slowing down.This is thanks to technology like the regenerative braking system, which recovers energy that would normally be lost and stores it in the battery for later use.And because they are all self-charging hybrids, their batteries never need to be plugged in.E-Car Club is promoting a special introductory offer to coincide with the launch which includes FREE letime membershipplus pound free driving credit.Simply visit: www.ecarclub join and enter code: WELCOMESB to claim this offer.

story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is set to consult on the catchment areas for two Selkirk primary schools.Following a decline in the number of pupils at Yarrow Primary School, council officers are looking at altering the catchment area to include homes that are currently within Philiphaugh Community Schoolrsquos catchment.The plans would mean that pupils from Yarrowford and Broadmeadows, to the west of Selkirk, would attend Yarrow Primary School instead of Philiphaugh School, which is in town.A report, due to go before Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive meeting on Tuesday  April, explains that a consultation will be carried out with parents prior to any boundary changes.The author of the report, interim service director for children and young people Stuart Easingwood, writes: ldquoThe proposed consultation will seek views on whether there is support for the proposal to amend the catchment areas.ldquoIt is not considered that the proposal will have a material impact on Philiphaugh Community School.ldquoThe number of children in the area under consideration area is relatively low and the Philiphaugh roll has been at a consistent level for a number of years.ldquoThere are currently  pupils at the school which equates to occupancy of %. The average occupancy over the last ten years has been  percent.ldquoIf there is a positive response to the proposal, and a formal recommendation is made to councillors to amend the catchment, it is proposed that pupils, from the Yarrowford and Broadmeadows area, currently attending Philiphaugh, can decide which school they would like to attend and council funded transport will be provided.ldquoThis arrangement will also apply to any future siblings.The consultation,approved by councillors on Tuesday, will run throughout May, culminating in two public meetings on Thursday, may , at Yarrow Primary School and Philiphaugh Community Schools, at .pm and .pm respectively.

title: beauty-students-hope-to-nail-a-place-in-national-qualifiers
story: BORDERS College Beauty Therapy students are hoping to make it through to the National Qualiers of the Beauty Therapy World Skills Competition.Students, Connie Lothian, along with model Kayleigh Scott, and Chloe Thomson, along with model Caitlan McGregor, study on the Beauty Therapy Level  course.The students have spent several weeks brushing up their skills and preparing for the competition, which focuses on the hand and face categories.The initial part of the competition started at the end of last month and involved the students submitting a photographic entry for initial assessment.They spent the day preparing their models to a high standard before professional photographer Phil Wilkinson was invited in to photograph the finished results.Phil spent the afternoon setting up ious photo shoots, which highlighted the best of their work, with the final pictures then submitted to the competition for assessment.The work of the students is now in the hands of the judges, and they face an anxious wait to seethey have been invited to the National Qualiers, which will take place this summer.If they qualy they will be invited to participate in the UK National Final at the NEC in November this year, as part of WorldSkills UK LIVE, the UKs largest interactive apprenticeships, skills and careers event.Heather Fisher, Curriculum Learning Manager, commented: ldquoFollowing on from the recent success of the Hairdressing and Fashion Make-up students at the AHT finals in Blackpool, we thought it would be a great idea for the Beauty Therapy students to be entered in to their own competition.ldquoThe students have been working exceptionally hard over the last month or so and their efforts have shown some excellent results.ldquoThe work the students created on the day of the photo shoot was outstanding and the final photographs highlighted this.ldquoWe should know whether we have qualied or not by May  and look forward to hearing from the judges. Fingers crossed we make it!Lecturer Gail Pow added: "This is a great opportunity for the students to showcase their skills.ldquoThe work they have put in to the competition is second to none and we hope they can secure a place in the next stage.ldquoThe photo shoot was a great experience for both students and lecturers and we are very excited to hear the feedback from the judges."

title: craig-keeps-it-in-the-family-with-standard-bearer-appointment
story: No Standard Bearer in Selkirkrsquos history can possibly have beenbetter prepared than Craig Monks.Not only is the -year-old fencer following in the footsteps of his grandfather, Drysdale, dad, Keith, and older brother, Rory, but his boss, James Cheyne, was also a Royal Burgh Standard Bearer in .Craig, who has been an Attendant four times since , couldnrsquot hide his delight after being carried around the streets of his ancient hometown.He told us: ldquoIrsquove been brought up with the Common Riding since I was a wee boy.ldquoIt wasnrsquot just Selkirk Common Riding, me and my brothers were dragged round every festival every year.ldquoI live in a house where everyone loves the Common Riding and therersquos always plenty of advice on offer.ldquoEven when I go to work Irsquove got James telling me what to expect.ldquoIrsquove waited a long time for this and so far itrsquos been unbelievable ndash nothing has ever compared to that moment the doors opened and I became the Standard Bearer.Hundreds had gathered in the Market Place to witness Standard Bearer elect Monks hoisted shoulder-high emerging from the Town Hall.And standing above on the balcony were parents, Keith and Iona, along with brothers, Rory and Kieran.Despite the threatening grey skies the rain stayed away. Selkirk Silver and Selkirk Flute bands, as always, created the traditional atmosphere that goes hand-in-hand with Appointment Night.And the foot followers were in good voice.Following the tour of the town, Standard Bearer elect Monks was joined by his  Attendants outside the Appointment Night Concert at the Victoria Halls.Adam Nichol, , Liam Cassidy, , Andrew McColm, , and -year-old Conall Fairbairn will have the honour of following Standard Bearer Monks around the Marches in June.Also preparing for June is the recently appointed Provost.Like Standard Bearer elect Monks, Keith Miller has a fine Common Riding pedigree, having been the Weavers Standard Bearer  years ago as well as holding the position of Deacon from  to .And he admits hersquos excited about what lies ahead.Provost Miller said: ldquoI know Craig and he will do a great job as Standard Bearer.ldquoMy own son, Darren, is also the Weavers Standard Bearer this year.ldquoItrsquos going to be a busy and enjoyable year for all of us.ldquoIrsquom honoured to be Provost and itrsquos been so far so good.Selkirk Common Riding takes place on Friday, June .

title: ancrum-set-for-art-bonanza
story: LOOKING for some culture this May Day bank holiday Ancrum has the answer.The village will be welcoming Art@Ancrum for another year, introducing visitors to three full days of local artists and artwork.Visitors can expect a wide iety of professional art and design-led work available to view and purchase.A mix of  established and new artists and makers will participate in the exhibitions and demonstrations over the bank holiday weekend.The event will include paintings, illustrations, ceramics, textiles, wood, sculpture, jewellery and more.Art@Ancrum is currently in its seventh year and the unique event is hoped to repeat their success by attracting visitors from Scotland, the UK, and beyond.Building on the success of the  lsquoCrossing Bordersrsquo Art Trail exhibition, a group of local participants proposed a new initiative, a long weekend of Art@Ancrum.Since then it has turned into an annual event, supported by the people of the village.Ian Oliver, a spokesperson for the event, said: ldquoArt@Ancrum has become an established favourite in the art world calendar.ldquoYou can enjoy a stroll around the covetable village of Ancrum and pop into some of the charming cottages that will be home to the exhibitions. A truly wonderful way to while away a few hours.The artwork can be found in  dferent venues including artists studios, the village hall and church, rustic outbuildings, and even the Bowling Club.Local pub, the Cross Keys, will also be full of art as it will also house a special exhibition called Absent Friends containing work by artists who cannot attend in person, but whose work is respected and admired by the community.To polish it all off, there will be food, Borders brewed beers and spirits and some cracking live outside entertainment, weather permitting.This year the chosen charity is the "My Namersquo Doddie Foundation".To raise money for the cause there will be collecting cans dotted around for contributions. And teas, coffees, cakes and scones will be served in the Village Hall thanks to the Roxburgh Federation of SWI.The art extravaganza will be held from Saturday, May  to Monday, May . Open from am to pm daily.For more information, check out the website www.artatancrum.org.uk

title: government-rules-against-west-lintons-hen-party-mansion
story: A BORDERS businessman has lost his battle to keep renting out his mansion for lsquoluxury hen partiesrsquo following a planning battle with the council.Michael Cameron, of West Linton, has been renting out the -square-foot Greenloaning Mansion, just north of West Linton, as a luxury getaway for groups of  to  guests, complete with cinema room, spa, two outdoor hot tubs, pool table and gym, since .Mr Cameron charges groups up to pound, for a one-week stay, and even offers chauffeur services in and out of Edinburgh in either a black Bentley, a white Maserati or blacked-out Range Rover. However, Mr Cameron had failed to noty Scottish Borders Council planners about the change of use, who found out once concerned neighbours began to complain about noise disturbances by rowdy hen parties.In November , Mr Cameron received an enforcement notice from the council outlining its grievances, which included concerns over noise disturbances, a detrimental impact on residential amenity and a breach of planning protocol.Mr Cameron subsequently appealed to the Scottish Governmentrsquos department for planning and environmental appeals , saying that because the property has been used for this purpose for more than ten years the council could no longer object to the change of use.The appeal statement also outlines the steps Mr Cameron has made in order to mitigate the noise disturbances from his property.This includes removing two hot tubs from the rear of the building, and instead installing a new one in the spa, which has triple-glazing to minimise noise impact.Mr Cameron has also proposed to remove the barbeque facility from the rear decking of the property, in an effort to stop groups of guests congregating outside.Finally, Mr Cameron has proposed employing a night manager to monitor the property and sound levels between pm and am on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, and to give the four closest neighbours a direct line to the night manager to raise any issues immediately.Despite this, the DPEA has ruled against the West Linton businessman, and has been two months to cease using the property as a party mansion.Chirs Norman, a DPEA reporter appointed by Scottish Ministers, writes in his ruling: ldquoBefore  November  the availability of lsquoGreenloaningrsquo for holiday letting, and its limited use for  weeks, was ordinarily incidental to its main use as a house.ldquoSome two or three years after  November  it ceased to be the appellantrsquos main residence.ldquoFrom  lsquoGreenloaningrsquo was continually promoted and used as self-catering accommodation for short-stay lets.ldquoOn the balance of probability and on the basis of the evidence before me I find that the unauthorised change of use of the house occurred between  November  and  November .ldquoTherefore the council is not time-barred from taking enforcement action and the appellantrsquos appeal fails.ldquoI find that the house is accessed from an unsurfaced road in the north-east part of West Linton and is in an area characterised by large, in the main, detached houses set in substantial garden grounds in a semi-rural part of the village.ldquoIts location some  metres from the A  and the centre of the village means that residents in the area enjoy a very high standard of amenity.ldquoI have studied the representations on the case and note the alleged impact on residential amenity caused by the use of the property for short-stay letting.ldquoI further note that the appellant has taken steps to curtail the effects of the unauthorised use, and in particular noise and alleged anti-social behaviour.ldquoI am also mindful of the support given by persons staying at lsquoGreenloaningrsquo to businesses in the village.ldquoHowever, I conclude that the unauthorised use of lsquoGreenloaningrsquo has an unacceptable impact on the character of the established amenity in this generally quiet part of West Linton.ldquoExternal activity can arise after . hours and a signicant change into the quiet residential area has been introduced.ldquoThe two-month time period for the cessation of the use is reasonable, given the impact of the unauthorised development on the amenity of this part of West Linton.

title: explorers-great-mystery-comes-to-borders-stages
story: A LIGHT-HEARTED romp featuring starvation, scurvy, cannibalism and some jolly tunes comes to the Borders next week.The new play by Peter Arnott for Mull Theatre, Unspotted Snow, is based on the tale of Sir John Franklinrsquos ill-fated expedition to discover the Northwest Passage.In , Franklin and  men sailed off to discover a route from the Atlantic to the Pacic via the north coast of Canada, but were never seen again.A bold and adventurous account of tragedy, mishap, folly, arrogance and madness, it also serves as a cautionary tale of true-blue British heroism ndash and some ruthless news management.After nine years, news of the expedition was at last brought to London by the remarkable Orcadian explorer and physician John Rae, who worked for the Hudsonrsquos Bay Company.The news he brought was both tragic and grizzly. Unfortunately for Rae, it was the wrong story ndash true, but wrong in that it was not the story that Victorian England wanted.Unspotted Snow is a play of two halves: the first set on the barren ice flows of the Arctic and the second in the equally inhospitable environment of Lady Jane Franklinrsquos drawing room.As playwright Arnott explained, unlike Franklin and the majority of th century British explorers, Rae was uninterested in conquest and the imposition of religious, commercial, or imperial norms on the wilderness.ldquoLike John Muir in Calornia, he anticipated a much more lsquomodernrsquo holistic approach to the natural world, not seeing people as being conquerors of empty space but as inhabitants of a planet shared with other forms of le, he said.The story of the expedition has fascinated the general public, scientists and explorers for over  years.From early findings of frozen corpses and a few artefacts to the very recent discoveries of the expeditionrsquos boats, the Erebusand the Terror , successive generations have been enthralled by the ambition and daring-do of the explorers and by their terrying, macabre fate.That fascination, and the split between two realities, is emphasised by the two-part nature of the play.ldquoIn the first half, a kind of horror-comedy, we have an encounter between three of the last survivors of Franklinrsquos expedition and some Inuit ladies to whom they utterly fail to explain themselves, explained Arnott.ldquoAnd then, in a curious echo of that, we have the inhospitable wilderness of Lady Franklinrsquos Drawing Room, where John Rae again finds himself telling a story that his audience simply cannot, or will not, understand.Unspotted Snow will be performed at the MacArts in Galashiels on Thursday, May  and the following evening at the Eastgate Theatre in Peebles.Tickets for the Galashiels performance, priced at pound and pound, are available from the box office at   .And the Eastgate performance tickets, priced at pound, pound and pound for Under s, are available on  , or online at www.eastgateartsBoth performances begin at .pm.

title: nostalgia-and-psycho-teachers-at-the-macarts
story: CELEBRATED and award-winning author Christopher Brookmyre brings his highly-entertaining new play to the Borders later this month.A Tale Etched In Blood And Hard Black Pencil is a hilarious Scottish black comedy performed by the Horsehead Theatre company.When a double murder reunites the classmates of St Elizabethrsquos Primary School, scores are settled, debts repaid and alliances forged.Some  years have passed but will those bonds still hold fast Brookmyre takes a nostalgic look at school days, filled with psycho teachers, class jokers and playground feuds.And it is all set to a cracking s s soundtrack!Following their  sell-out run at Edinburgh Fringe and at the international crime writing festival, Bloody Scotland, Horsehead Theatre are touring A Tale Etched In Blood And Hard Black Pencil throughout .Brookmyre himself admits Horsehead Theatre have produced an utterly brilliant adaptation.As the play contains very strong language and scenes of a sexual nature, it is suitable for s and over only.A Tale Etched In Blood And Hard Black Pencil will be performed at the MacArts on Saturday, May .Tickets, priced at pound , are available from the box office on   .Doors open at pm with the play starting at .pm.

title: travelling-borderer-returns-from-charitable-adventure
story: A BORDERS man has spoken of his eye-opening experiences after two years of travelling the world to assist those in need.Dominic Taddei, who grew up in Hawick and spent almost five years serving his country with the Kings Own Scottish Borderers, decided to leave the Borders behind in .He sold off many of his possessions to fund a two-year volunteering mission across Africa and has ed with a renewed sense of perspective.During his travels across Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda Dominic witnessed violent election riots, contracted Malaria and suffered a iety of broken bones having fallen down a storm drain.Dominic, who is , told the Border : ldquoWe really donrsquot have any idea of how others live on the other side of the world in some of the poorest countries on earth.ldquoI spent most of my time living in slums, which ied from corrugated houses to mud houses with grass thatched roofs.During his time in Africa, Dominic acted as a trustee for Roll Out the Barrel Trust UK, a project that aims to help with water supply issues in some of the worldrsquos poorest countries.Dominic also helped found a charity in Kenya, The Sunflower Community Orphans Support Project.The organization helps feed orphaned children, many of whom are affected by poverty and HIV AIDS, by using the proceeds of a cafeacute selling food to the public.Dominic fully embraced the lestyle of the local community, enduring the same daily struggles faced by the local population.ldquoI experienced what it was like to have electricity and water shortages and to fetch and carry drinking water.ldquoFor the two years I went without washing machines, showers, fridges, cookers, TV or a flushing toilet.His desire to experience the tough reality of le in these societies is perhaps unsurprising given his previous holiday destinations have included North Korea, Chernobyl and the annexed Crimean Peninsula.Despite the dficulties faced by the communities he assisted, Dominic was struck by the gratitude and positivity he encountered. He said: ldquoThe best part was seeing the smiles and laughs of the people I helped.ldquoThey were grateful and happy, and because I lived like the majority of the people in the slum they made feel a part of the community - I really did feel like it was home.This sense of community was demonstrated when a newly born child was named after him, an experience which left Dominic ldquospeechless and overwhelmed.The experiences of his spartan existence during his charitable travels, and the positivity of communities with so few of the things we take for granted, have shaped Dominicrsquos attitude to le since ing to the UK in March.He added: ldquoAfter selling most of my things to help fund this mission I now own very few items and the ones I do own I appreciate more.ldquoI appreciate things like electricity, running water, showers and fridges.ldquoI now live a fairly simple le and, to be honest, I feel happier doing so.

title: how-much-has-duncs-big-quiz-raised-so-far
story: ONE of the biggest quizzes to ever take place in the Scottish Borders has now raised well over pound, for charity since it began.The Big Quiz this year saw over  people cram into the Volunteer Hall in Galashiels, with over pound, generated on the night for Prostate Scotland charity.This years winners were The Brownlees who won by half a point from Ginrsquoll Fix It, followed by #thatsjustrude in third place.The event is now in its eighth year, and has been organised each time by Lucy McAneny in memory of her father, Duncan Paterson who passed away a decade ago.Lucy said: ldquoA huge thank you once again to all who helped in advance and on the night, as well as all the teams who entered and have now helped raise over pound, for Prostate Scotland which is an excellent charity which is close to the hearts of our family.ldquoWe look forward to seeing you all again in .

title: shelagh-saddles-up-for-850-miles-humanitarian-charity-cycle
story: A SEMI-RETIRED doctor from the Borders is prescribing some personal pain in a bid to raise much-needed funds for a humanitarian charity that helps survivors of torture.Shelagh King has been delivering babies at Borders General Hospitals maternity ward for decades.And she has also been active member of the Amnesty International inspired Freedom from Torture charity.Later this summer the -year-old from Newstead will team up with a fellow supporter from Edinburgh, Moira Dunworth, to raise vital funds by cycling some  miles around all of the charitys UK centres.Shelagh told us: "We hope to raise awareness about the Freedom from Torture and the people it supports, meet many other supporters, and raise money for the important work."Freedom from Torture provides counselling, medical evidence of torture for legal cases, and general support for people who have suffered torture."Now that I am semi-retired I have the time and when it was mentioned at the AGM that they were looking for people to join in with Moira on part of the fundraising cycle I decided to sign up and give the whole challenge a go."Shelagh and Moira will leave Hastings on Monday, July  and cycle for the next  days zig-zagging across the UK until they reach Edinburgh at the end of the month.Although Shelagh is an enthusiastic member of athletics clubs Gala Harriers and Lauderdale Limpers she admits shes a novice on two wheels.And in preparation for the Cycle Against Torture she is being coached by friend, Tish Mitchell.Shelagh added: "We are working up my distance slowly and have so far managed  miles in one day."I will certainly be well-trained by the time we set off from Hastings."One of the first patients to receive help from Freedom from Torture was Eric Lomax from Berwick Upon Tweed, whose story was told in the film The Railwayman.Eric was tortured as a prisoner of war in Burma.Nowadays people from all over the world who have suffered torture benefit from the charity.Joining Shelagh and Moira for part of their mammoth cycle challenge will be Syrian refugee Violet, who now lives in Glasgow.And they have also won support from world-record cyclist and broadcaster Mark Beaumont.He said: "I am inspired by the efforts of Moira and Shelagh, both retired and taking on an epic cycle ride from Hastings to Edinburgh alongside Violet, a young Syrian refugee."Freedom from Torture is a brilliant grassroots charity providing medical and psychological care for survivors of torture here in the UK and I am sure that this Cycle against Torture will do brilliantly at raising awareness and funds."Chapeau ladies for this adventure of a letime."To support Shelaghs cycle challenge visit https:www.justgiving fundraising shelagh-king

title: council-backs-plans-for-ettrick-4g
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has approved plans to bring G mobile coverage to the Ettrick Valley.Warrington-based WHP Telecoms plans on erecting a  metre-high G tower on Deephope Hill, just off the B between Eskdalemuir and Ettrick.The plans have largely been welcomed by local residents, who cite the current lack of mobile phone signal as a detriment to both the quality of le in the valley and the ability of businesses to thrive.However, they also attracted nine letters of objection, which cited concerns over the height of the mast, the impact on the landscape and the potential detrimental impact on property prices.One supporter, Ogilvie Jackson, of Selkirk, appeared before Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee on Monday to urge councillors to support the plans.He told the committee: ldquoWe have been lobbying very hard to get mobile coverage in the valley.ldquoFor the last three years our neighbours at Ettrick village have enjoyed good coverage due to government funded masts that tower over the settlement.ldquoThe mast before you will give us near perfect G coverage for the Ettrick Valley.ldquoThe proposed site could not be better. In fact compared to some masts in the Borders itrsquos very discreet.ldquoMany motorists have been stranded and unable to secure help because of the lack of phone signal. This mast will make our valley a safer and more self-reliant place to live.ldquoI would say this to the objectors: itrsquos easy to object to a phone mast just because you donrsquot like phone masts. If that happened everywhere there would be no mobile coverage in the country.Councillors sitting on the planning and building standards committee were advised by planning officers that the benefits outweigh the impact of the mastBarry Fotheringham, the councilrsquos principal planning officer, told the committee: ldquoThe proposed mast and associated equipment form part of a national programme to deliver a new mast network and telecommunications coverage in hard to reach areas in Scotland that do not benefit from mobile telephone connectivity.ldquoThe proposed mast will be visible in the landscape but it is considered that the benefits of having a strong telecommunications signal in the Ettrick Valley outweigh the limited and localised landscape and visual impacts.ldquoThe proposed mast will be future-proofed so that it can accommodate other users and G networks. This will avoid the need for a proleration of other masts locally.ldquoThe proposed development complies with the principal policy requirements of the local development plan and is consistent with ensuring that an improved digital infrastructure is available, to ensure people and communities are better connected.While discussing the proposals, councillors were broadly in favour of granting planning permission.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing said: ldquoI have no problem with this application whatsoever. Itrsquos time the Ettrick Valley was brought into the st century.ldquoI absolutely think this is the right decision.Kelso and District councillor Simon Mountford also spoke in favour of the proposals: ldquoIrsquom delighted by this. In this time and age it is unreasonable to expect communities to exist without mobile phone coverage.ldquoAny visual impact is completely outweighed by the economic and social benefits of allowing this application to proceed.Councillors voted unanimously to approve the application.
