story: THE major delay in completing work on an environmental improvement scheme in Irish Street in Downpatrick has been branded a ldquodisgrace by a local politician.Councillor Dermot Curran has this week called for an urgent meeting to be arranged between traders and senior officials from a number of government departments involved in the project to discuss what went wrong and what can be done to ensure the project is completed as soon as possible.Last week the Recorder revealed that Irish Street traders are furious that work on the project is to take more than twice as long to complete than originally planned.Work to provide new paving, street lighting and street furniture was due to complete at the end of March, but contractors will not now be finished their work until the end of June.And, to compound tradersrsquo frustration, once contractors move off site, Irish Street will be completely closed to traffic for a short period to allow the main road to be resurfaced, taking the scheme into July.There have been a series of issues associated with the regeneration scheme with the initial start date delayed as Phoenix Gas took longer than expected to complete its work at this part of the town.Signicant issues have also arisen with the foundations for the blast wall which surrounded the former police base and problems with the sewer network.Cllr Curran wants senior representatives from Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Departments for Infrastructure and Communities to meet with traders and insists that NI Water must also be represented.ldquoThe public realm scheme has been delayed by over three months, raw sewage has been running down the street and, most shockingly, traders have not been kept abreast of the reasons for the delay, he declared.ldquoThe Irish Street project was due to complete inside three months but it will now be early July and what those responsible for the work do not realise is that businesses are being affected across the town, not just those in Irish Street.Cllr Curran said the delay in completing the scheme is having a major impact on the town centre, revealing that he has heard reports that the number of people using the Irish Street car park has reduced since work on the public realm scheme started.He said with trading conditions dficult enough at the best of times, the last thing business owners need is for the one-way system remaining in place in Irish Street for another two months.ldquoThe delay in completing this scheme is nothing short of disgraceful and questions need answered. In addition, traders should be provided with weekly progress briefings as a matter of courtesy. The fact this has not happened is deeply disappointing, Cllr Curran continued.The local politician said the temporary one-way system is impacting on traffic volumes in St Patrickrsquos Avenue and Market Street in particular, with some shoppers opting to avoid Downpatrick as work on the public realm scheme continues.Cllr Curran also suggested that the delay in delivering the public realm scheme would ldquosimply not be tolerated in any other area. He claimed that taking twice as long to complete a scheme would not be accepted in areas like Newry, Lisburn or Belfast.He declared: ldquoMany businesses in Downpatrick are suffering as the result of an unacceptable delay. The clear evenings are now here, so why canrsquot contractors be asked to work longer to complete the scheme sooner ldquoWhile I accept that the delays may be the result of unexpected circumstances, surely the trick is to come up with imaginative solutions to get the work completed as soon as possible  The suggested completion date at the end of June needs to be reassessed now.Cllr Curran said he plans to contact the ious government departments and agencies to arrange a meeting with Irish Street traders and hopes it will take place as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle park needs management strategy
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council officials have been asked to develop a management strategy for an open area at the rear of Newcastlersquos Donard Park and adjacent woodland.The request has been made by Mournes councillor Willie Clarke, who recently tabled a council motion urging the local authority to contact the Annesley Estate with a view to leasing land it owns at this part of the town.Cllr Clarke is keen for this to happen to enable the council to maintain what he described as an ldquoattractive area to complement existing amenities in Donard Park.He believes the council can help play a key role in improving the recreational, health and well-being of local people, in tandem with enhancing the resortrsquos tourism potential,the area and its important habitat are managed properly.While his recent motion was referred to the local authorityrsquos Economic Regeneration and Tourism Committee for debate, Cllr Clarke said that,re-elected, one of his key priorities will be shaping the future management of a ldquo fabulous landscape and woodland, preserving it for future generations.He continued: ldquoThe upper green area needs to be incorporated in the future management of Donard Wood, while the pathways and signage for visitors need to be improved for visitors entering the main route used by hill walkers heading into the Mournes to climb Slieve Donard.ldquoIn the short term, I have made representations to council officials to carry out maintenance improvements at the Shanslieve Drive entrance to Donard Park where visitors are greeted by rusting litter bins, council signage dating back to the s and a potholed surface.Cllr Clarke said these are improvements that need to carried out immediately.Also this week, he has called on the local authority to repaint the historic archway at the entrance to Donard Park car park.He said: ldquoRepainting the archway will also improve the appearance and aesthetics of the entrance into Donard Park and I have requested that the work is undertaken as quickly as possible, Cllr Clarke added..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle rock star’s intimate solo album
story: THE discovery of a random white feather gave The Answerrsquos frontman Cormac Neeson a sign of hope at the most desperate time in his le mdash and the inspiration for his first solo album.The Newcastle rocker has just released a searingly intimate and personal album called White Feather with ten tracks which deal with his eldest son Dabhoacutegrsquos fight to be born and for le itself.Launching at Belfast venue The Black Box on May , the  year-old will give his most stripped back performance as an artist as he tours with the album over the coming months.His old friends, The Unholy Gospel Band, with bass guitarist, Downpatrickrsquos own Eamon Hanlon, will be joining him for the big night.Cormac also has a new single out from the album, Broken Wing, a country-inspired track with blues backing choir that will resonate with people whether they are a parent or not.His rock vocals have given way to a deeper, introspective sound that is still etched with emotion.The  year-old singer, who once toured with rock legends AD DC, says he the experience of nearly losing his son from being born prematurely at  weeks has changed him.Dabhoacuteg, who has Downrsquos Syndrome, weighed only lb oz when he was born. After spending his first four months in a hospital neo-natal unit and undergoing heart surgery on his first birthday, he is now four. Thankfully, Dabhoacuteg has turned the corner despite overcoming serious medical obstacles in his short le.Dabhoacuteg and his  month-old brother, Conall, mean everything to Cormac and his we Louise, who now live in Belfast.ldquoWhenever you have a sick child and you go through an ordeal like that with your family, it does definitely alter your perception and you come out the other side of it changed, said Cormac.ldquoYou just look at le in a dferent way. You appreciate stuff that you never appreciated because yoursquore not sitting in an intensive care unit in the Royal [Victoria Hospital]. Anything is better than that.The couple only had a few weeks to privately celebrate getting pregnant with their first child when Louise had to be rushed into hospital.They initially were advised that pregnancy was lost as it was so early but were told to come back to hospital in a few weeks time.ldquoIt was the longest two weeks in my le, recalls Cormac. ldquoThe night before we were due to go the hospital I went out for a walk in the Mournes. I was a bit raging at the world and screaming up to the heavens asking to be give a sign that everything was going to be ok.ldquoI was literally stopped dead in my tracks with this little splash of white high in a tree. I climbed up into the tree to see what it was and it was a white feather.ldquoI had always been brought up to believe that white feathers symbolised new le. I couldnrsquot believe that I spotted it at that time and brought it back down. I had a feeling then that everything was ok. The next day we went to hospital and sure enough there was this tiny mustard seed on the scan with the most giant heartbeat you ever saw in your le. It was the beginning of what was to be a most tumultuous journey and the beginning of where we are now, having an amazing four-year-old and a baby.ldquoDabhoacuteg really is a warrior. Hersquos been through more than me and most people ever will in their lives.Long-term fans of The Answer may be surprised at one of their leaders heading to Nashville to write and record the album.But as Cormac tells it, itrsquos just the way it was meant to be.He went to the home of country music in  on a songwriting course to help write songs for other artists but ended up literally pouring his heart and pain out in the songs mdash in time-honoured country music fashion.ldquoItrsquos not a country record but you can tell it is recorded in Nashville, said Cormac.ldquoThere is an awful lot of soul to it and a bit of subtley to it as well as it allowed me to express myself in the way that I needed to at this point in my le. I needed to make a record that reflected that switch in the way I see le.The Nashville approach to writing songs was a more reflective experience for Cormac that what he is used to with bandmates Paul Mahon, Mickey Waters and James Heatley.ldquoIt was just a completely dferent approach to songwriting that I had been used to doing for  years with The Answer, said Cormac. ldquoItrsquos a hard rocking blues band and a lot of our songs are written with the volume pedal turned up rfing away, having a good time and letting songs organically develop.ldquoIn Nashville, you sit in a room with two other people and an accustic guitar and you have a long conversation about your le and what you might want to write about. I found once we were locked into the message we wanted to put across in the song everything  fell into place. We basically wrote songs in the morning and recorded in the afternoon as thatrsquos what the studio expected.ldquoA lot of what Irsquom singing about on this record just would not work on a record from The Answer because it wouldnrsquot be appropriate. Rock and roll is loud and le-affirming. While a lot of these songs are le-affirming, they are in a completely dferent way.Cormac assures the bandrsquos devoted following that they have stockpiled a supply of new songs and will be coming out with a new album.Addressing his own personal hiatus, Cormac added: ldquoIrsquom still the same guy I was in The Answer and will be again when The Answer makes our next record. I just needed to get into the right room with the right writers making the right music.White Feather album will be released on April  before a tour kicks off in the UK on May  for a run of seven support shows followed by six Irish headline dates. For show dates visit http:www.cormacneeson or https:www.facebook cormacneesonsolo ..prettyPhoto

title: School of Lifesaving staff complete Makaton course
story: DOWNPATRICK School of Lesaving has been taking part in a new training course.Rhianna Rooney and Yvonne Smyth, who are both senior lesaving teachers at Downpatrick School of Lesaving, attended a Full Makaton for Beginners Course held recently in Castlewellan.Aware of how beneficial the use of Makaton could be to the coaches of DSL, Yvonne approached the course tutor, Cynthia Robinson, with an idea that could assist the lesaving club.In a joint collaboration, a number of lesaving signs and signals were consolidated into a Makaton course specic to lesaving.Yvonne said: ldquoWe are trying to offer inclusiveness within our sport, so we fully understand and appreciate the need for Makaton training.ldquoWe have a team of  senior and junior volunteer coaches, with an additional eight parent helpers, delivering our lesaving skill to approximately  local young people ages from six years up.ldquoWe have had great satisfaction knowing that we can try to reach out to all.Downpatrick School of Lesaving would like to thank Cynthia for her help and support..prettyPhoto

title: Sinn Fein leader McDonald visits Downpatrick
story: SINN Fein president Mary Lou McDonald was in Downpatrick on Monday as part of a visit to the district ahead of tomorrowrsquos local government election.She was welcomed to the town by party representative Oonagh Hanlon and visited the Pepper Johns Community Centre in Church Avenue and the grave of United Irishman Thomas Russell in the grounds of Down Parish Church.The Sinn Fein party leader also visited the grave of St Patrick at Down Cathedral where she met the Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull, and Dr Tim Campbell, Director of the St Patrick Centre, which is dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint.Accompanying the Sinn Fein president were South Down MP Chris Hazzard, Emma Rogan MLA and council election candidates Jordan Madden, who is standing in the Downpatrick DEA with Mrs Hanlon, and Slieve Croobrsquos Cathy Mason.Mrs Hanlon said she was delighted to welcome the party president to Downpatrick where she enjoyed the ldquovery unique and enduring heritage the local area has to offer, also meeting a wide range of local community leaders.ldquoI want to especially thank Alison and everyone at Pepper Johns Community Centre who made Mary Lou feel very welcome. She was clearly in awe at the fantastic work they do for the local community, said Mrs Hanlon.ldquoThanks also to Dean Hull for hosting an extremely engaging visit to Down Cathedral and the world renowned grave of St Patrick.Mrs Hanlon added: ldquoLocal people are understandably very proud of the rich, enduring Patrician heritage in these parts and itrsquos great to see such enthusiasm from yet another national political figure following the recent visit of Taacutenaiste Simon Coveney..prettyPhoto

title: Sizzling Down lift All Ireland title
story: A VIRTUOSO attacking display from Sorcha McCartan and a defensive masterclass from team captain Blanaid Savage enabled Down to lt the All-Ireland B Shield at a cold and wind-swept Inniskeen Grattans, Monaghan, on Saturday afternoon.The final scoreline was a bit rough on a game Meath outfit and two goals from the predatory Saoirse Sands, in as many minutes just before the break, proved the dference between the sides.Down started in a hurry with midfielders Megan OrsquoBoyle and Anna McKee seeing plenty of the ball and they wasted no time in getting their forwards involved.As early as the second minute, Down were awarded a free on the m line.Everyone thought that McCartan would just pop the sliotar over the bar for an easy point, but she had other ideas and blasted a fiercely-hit shot to the back of the net.Down continued to ask all the early questions, but two minutes later they were found wanting at the back and when their defence failed to deal with a Jessica Potterton free, Ciara Foley swooped to bring the sides level with an instinctive finish.McCartan edged Down back in front with a well-taken point, but two unanswered scores, one from the diligent Potterton and one from Sonia Leonard gave Meath a - to - lead after  minutes.That lead didnrsquot last long as the inspirational McCartan effortlessly lofted over a rsquo to level the scores yet again with  minutes gone.Meath were wining a lot of lsquodirty ballrsquo in the engine room, but superb defensive play from Savage and Orlaith OrsquoRourke kept them at bay.However, Potterton converted another free in the st minute to give her side a - to - lead and when Emer Fagan stretched that lead to two points, Down suddenly looked vulnerable.With  minutes gone Bredaghrsquos Aoibhinn Brentnall reduced the leeway before sizzling Sands stunned Meath.Her first goal came in the th minute after the Meath lsquokeeper was unable to clear a lofted effort from Beth Fitzpatrick. Sands struck with all the stealth and power that her dad Noel displayed for Down hurlers for many years as she beat Katie Smith all ends up with a clinical finish.Meath were now on the ropes and Sands delivered a second knock-out blow a minute later when she again ghosted in to direct a McCartan pass to the net and give down a - to - interval lead.Meath had the wind advantage after the break, but it was Down and the unrelenting McCartan who took centre stage.Two sensational points from the Castlewellan teenager, a daughter of former Down All-Ireland medal winner Greg in , stretched Downrsquos lead to seven points with only five minutes of the second half played.All credit to Meath, they steadfastly refused to throw in the towel and a Foley point left them trailing - to - after  minutes.It wax at this stage that Savage played a real captainrsquos role from her central half back role. She was simply imperious, plucking the sliotar out of the air and then sending it forward for her team-mates to chase.Meath went close to giving Down a fright in the rd minute when an explosive shot from Fagan rattled off the crossbar and was cleared to safety, but other than that, little got past Savage.McCartan and Leonard swapped points as the game drew to a close, but Down had no intention of relinquishing their grip on the game and refused to give Meath any more scores.Down: Niamh Sharkey, Orlaith OrsquoRourke, Hannah Toner, Alice Coulter, Isabella OrsquoHare, Blanaid Savage, Niamh Dempster, Megan OrsquoBoyle, Anna McKee, Cerys Clarke, Sorcha McCartan , Saoirse Sands , Gerra McGrattan, Aoibhinn Brentnall , Beth Fitzpatrick. Subs: Aimee Mallon for Toner, Toner for OrsquoRourke, Alanna Hagan for McGrattan, Colleen McConnell, Bronagh Donaghy, Olivia Blaney, Eden Casey, Hannah Duffy, Roisin McPolin, Niamh Burns, Chloe McConville, Caitlin Fitzpatrick, Aoe McCann.Meath: Katie Smith, Caitlin Hamilton, Abbye Donnelly, Sophie Healy, Kate Smith, Aine Cooke, Hazel OrsquoReilly-Higgins, Ellen Brogan, Jessica Potterton , Sonia Leonard , Emer Fagan , Rachael Fraughan, Ellen OrsquoHara, Ciara Foley , Taylor Stack. Subs: Andrea McBride for Brogan, Francesca McKenna for Fraughan.  Down -Meath -ALL-IRELAND MINOR B SHIELD FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: St John’s GAC charity fashion show
story: A FASHION show which evokes the glamorous style worn by your mother or grandmother in the s visits the area on Saturday night.St Johnrsquos GAC in Drumnaquoile is hosting the show from the Living Vintage Company as a fundraiser in aid of local people travelling to Romania with Habitat for Humanity and the Centre for Cancer Research and Cell Biology at QUB.Living Vintage is a travelling fashion show where models wear a magnicent collection of some of the most stylish haute couture of the forties and fties in a great atmosphere of fun and nostalgia.Owned by sisters Bridget Owens and Marian Keenan, Living Vintage is a not-for-profit organisation.All monies raised are donated to Cancer Research at Queens University Belfast and Habitat for Humanity.The evening will showcase day dresses, suits and evening wear and is rounded of with a stunning bridal show.Bridget said: ldquoLiving Vintage evenings are great fun with plenty of laughs and many happy nostalgic memories.ldquoWe are extremely proud of our collection of authentic forties and fties fashion and all the outfits are accessorised with the appropriate vintage hats, gloves, bags, jewellery and of course, seamed stockings. Of course, some local ladies will also be on the catwalk.Doors open .pm for show at . and tickets are available from Smythrsquos shop, Newcastle, and JRrsquoS, Main St Castlewellan or by ringing Alicia on   and Marianne on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Strictly dancing at Newcastle school
story: A NEWCASTLE primary school are to host a Strictly Come Dancing fundraiser to help raise money for the school.St Maryrsquos Primary School will be staging the night at Slieve Donard Resort and Spa next Saturday, May .Q Radiorsquos Ryan A promises to bring a pinch of razzmatazz to the dance extravaganza as hersquoll be acting as compere for the evening.Dancers include teachers, classroom assistants, parents and past pupils. There will be two fabulous dance demonstrations from European Argentina Tango champions, Anna Arriza DrsquoEste and Marco de Camillis, and  Irish dancing world champions Orlaith Bradley and David Carberry.Jenni Maguire, a teacher at the school, has been putting the dancers through their paces along with former All-Ireland Ballroom champion and choreographer Graham Jack.The event promises to be a great night of entertainment, says Graham,with demonstrations from the world champion Irish dancers to kick start the night followed by couples taking to the stage with a selection of Latin and ballroom dances.He said: ldquoI am really excited about our event. It is a great opportunity to bring the school and community together for what promises to be a real dance spectacular, while raising money for our school.ldquoI couldnrsquot do what these dancers have done. They deserve great credit for putting two dance routines together in such a short period of time.ldquoThe contestants seem to have enjoyed the build up. While there has been pressure due to the time scale in preparation and the work load involved, there have been no tears or tantrums.He added. ldquoThe practices have been good fun. There have been plenty of laughs. The iniduals and couples mix well and we all get on the best. But when the hard work needs to be done, they take it very seriously.Jenni said the couples have put in many hours of rehearsals, given freely of their time and have shown great dedication.She said: ldquoSome have revealed much hidden talent in rehearsals and head judge, UTVrsquos Rita Fitzgerald, will have a tough job on her hands but with the help of the  and votes by the audience on the night the Strictly Ball could be a closely fought battle.One of the contestants, Claire Toner, whose son Dylan is a P pupil at the school, said: ldquoI volunteered as I wanted to do something dferent. It was a case of challenging myself and trying something fun and exciting.One person who has taken it all in her stride is classroom assistant Rachel Lowey. A past pupil of the school, she is paired with another former pupil and friend Shane Kearney.She said: ldquoLike Claire, I wanted to learn something new. Never in a million years did I think Irsquod be dancing on the same stage as some of my old teachers and classroom assistants.None of the dancers have experienced formal dance training before and for some it has been very dficult attending the twice weekly rehearsals.ldquoAs enjoyable as itrsquos been, one Strictly is my limit, said school principal Philip Fusco. ldquoWe hope this will be a superb event, not just for the school community of St Maryrsquos.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming everyone on the night and I have no doubt every guest will leave with a spring in their step.Tickets are available from the school office and are priced at pound for adult sand pound concession. You can also show your support and make a donation through JustGiving page.Many of the businesses, parents, friends and family have already shown their support by sponsoring a dancer. The school would like to express their heartfelt gratitude for their support.Sponsors include: McKeeverrsquos Chemist, Property Directions, ActiSport, Nutty Chef, Cocorsquos, Quinnrsquos, Diamond Patrsquos, Smallrsquos Body Repair and Paintworx, ADS Mechanical Ltd, DTS Plumbing and Heating, Mortgage and Insurance Directions, Mark Samuel Haulage, Kelly Brothers Building Contractors, Medicare, Donard Wines, Tap Room in the Donard Bar, Matthew Toner Electrics  Lick Gelato, Joe Quality Meats, Fitzpatrickrsquos Car and Commercial Repair, ADHD Parent Support Group, Shimna Cafe, Protamino Nutrition Ltd, Blue Beans and BodyRox..prettyPhoto

title: Vandals target playground days after opening
story: THOUGHTLESS vandals have been criticised for damaging play equipment at a recently refurbished play park at the Westlands estate in Crossgar.Community worker Paul Teggart and Rowallane councillors Terry Andrews and Patrick Brown are angry that literally within days of the new facility being opened the equipment was needlessly damaged.Mr Teggart, who worked hard to persuade Newry, Mourne and Down Council to upgrade a previously dilapidated play facility at the estate, said what happened had left him lost for words.ldquoThe new play facility was opened on Tuesday of last week an damaged just a matter of days later. This senseless vandalism has to stop and stop now, he declared.ldquoThe play equipment was specically designed for small children and it is my understanding that the names of people who were spotted in the vicinity of the playground when it was vandalised have been handed over to the authorities.Mr Teggart said Crossgar was a village proud of its mixed community with people getting on well together and working in unison to make it a welcoming and vibrant place.ldquoWe all get along with each other but it would appear that there are several youths who are determined to cause harm and have no respect for anyone or indeed young childrenrsquos play equipment, he continued.Mr Teggart added: ldquoWestlands residents are rightly upset with one suggesting to me that whoever was responsible should be made to pay for the damage they have caused.Cllr Andrews said this ldquowanton act of vandalism was totally out of order and uncalled for, emphasising that it was children who suffered as a result of the ldquodespicable action of others.ldquoI have made local council officials aware of what happened and and hope that the damaged equipment can be replaced. I was proud to see a play park which had been neglected for years rejuvenated, but the damage to the equipment is so disappointing.Cllr Andrews said he had many good memories of growing up in Westlands, explaining that after years of having nothing, it was ldquowonderful to see the play park rejuvenated for so many to enjoy.He continued: ldquoI hope those responsible will be apprehended. The message must go out that this kind of behaviour will not be tolerated.Cllr Andrews said many people worked hard to persuade the local council to redevelop the Westlands play park and are bitterly disappointed that their commitment and dedication to the local community is not shared by others.Cllr Brown said he was ldquoshocked to learn that play equipment had been damaged describing those responsible as ldquothoughtless vandals.He continued: ldquoAll councillors worked hard to deliver this upgraded play park for the community and to see it so needlessly damaged in the first week it has been open is so disappointing and adds to the ongoing anti-social behaviour problem in Crossgar.Cllr Brown said he met with Mr Teggart at the play park to inspect the damage and discuss how the local authority and PSNI can stop such ldquoreckless behaviour in the future.He added: ldquoThis sort of action cannot continue and those responsible will be held accountable..prettyPhoto

title: Voters take to the polls
story: VOTERS go to the polls across the district tomorrow to elect  councillors to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.Seventy one candidates are contesting the seats up for grabs in the Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob, Mournes, Crotlieve, Slieve Gullion and Newry areas.With the final day of canvassing already underway and candidates targeting any remaining undecided voters, all eyes will be on the magical turnout number which could decide success or failure for some.Turnout in the  council election was just over % which saw almost , people visiting polling stations across the district.As the local council prepares for its second four year term, Sinn Fein and the SDLP will be battling to become the largest party and it is certainly all to play for.Both parties currently have  councillors with Sinn Fein sources quietly confident that the party will have increased its number of seats once the final result has been declared.What is clear is that the final outcome of tomorrowrsquos election is the toughest to call in decades given the number of interesting battles taking place right across the district.Locally, all eyes will be on Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob and The Mournes which are intriguing to say the least, with the outcome potentially resulting in a dramatic change in the political landscape and some high profile figures losing out.In Downpatrick, attention will centre on the battle between Sinn Fein and the SDLP for electoral supremacy in an area where five seats are available.The SDLPrsquos Dermot Curran, Gareth Sharvin and John Trainor are out to retain their seats, with Sinn Fein aiming to ensure that Oonagh Hanlon and Jordan Madden will secure seats on the local authority for the first time.However, Independent councillor Cadogan Enright firmly intends to retain his seat, with strong support from a number of leading community groups in Downpatrick and Lecale.Add Aontuacute , the Green Party , Alliance , the DUPand UUPinto the mix and the expected dog fight for the fth seat could well be decided by transfers.In Rowallane, Independent candidate Martyn Todd and Sinn Feinrsquos Marianne Cleary will try to upset the current status quo in an area where the five seats are shared between the DUP, UUP, SDLP and Alliance.Sinn Fein has never held a seat in Rowallane before, but clinching one in a traditional unionist stronghold would represent a seismic sht.The SDLPrsquos Terry Andrews topped the Rowallane poll in , but was only  votes ahead of the UUPrsquos Robert Burgess, who is confident his running mate, Walter Lyons, who polled  first preference votes five years ago, can join him in the debating chamber.Lyons is the only Ballynahinch-based candidate contesting the poll, with DUP sources confident that Billy Walker and Harry Harvey will retain their seats. But with no TUV candidate, what will the  voters who backed Philip Hamilton in  do this time around Independent candidate Todd is expected to eat into sitting Alliance councillorrsquos Patrick Brownrsquos vote, with the Green Party intent on making an impression through Emma Cairns. Aontuacutersquos Liam Mulhern is contesting his first election and with  candidates chasing five seats the election count will be a particularly nervous affair.In Slieve Croob, the SDLP is keen to grab two of the five seats up for grabs with current encumbent Mark Murnin, the local councilrsquos current chairman, joined by party stalwart Hugh Gallagher.Sinn Fein has made its intention clear by fielding three candidates. Republicans currently hold two seats through Roacuteisiacuten Howell and John Rice and are aiming to ensure through the partyrsquos tried and trusted vote management system that Drumaness woman Cathy Mason will also secure a seat.Sitting DUP councillor Garth Craig is not seeking re-election with the party selecting Maynard Hanna to defend his seat, while Alan Lewis is flying the flag for the Ulster Unionists.Alliance currently hold a seat in Slieve Croob through Andy McMurray but he surprised many byopting to stand in the Mournes area, with his position being contested by university graduate Gregory Bain from Clough.The Mournes is another intriguing battleground where former South Down Ulster Unionist MLA Harold McKee is bidding to make ato local politics and the SDLP is aiming toits sitting councillors, Laura Devlin and Brian Quinn.However, Sinn Fein has an eye on one of the SDLP seats and is fielding three candidates, sitting councillors Willie Clarke and Sean Doran alongside Leanne McEvoy.Henry Reilly topped the poll in  while standing on a UKIP ticket. Now an Independent Unionist, he looks set to retain his seat alongside DUP stalwart Glyn Hanna, with all eyes on Alliancersquos Andrew McMurray following his switch from Slieve Croob..prettyPhoto

title: Zak tops Wicklow qualifiers
story: NEWCASTLE ACrsquos Zak Hanna has been selected to represent Ireland in the upcoming European Mountain Running Championships which take place in the scenic Swiss town of Zermatt, at the foot of the world famous Matterhorn Mountain.Living on the slopes of Slieve Croob outside Dromara, Zak travelled down to Wicklow on Saturday to compete in the trial race which would select the team to travel to Switzerland.With this yearrsquos race an uphill only race, compared to last yearrsquos championship being an lsquoup and downrsquo race, runners competing in the trial started at Crone Woods car park on the edge of the Wicklow Mountains and climb along the Wicklow Way trails before entering the open mountain and begin the long and steep ascent to the summit of Djouce Mountain at  mabove sea level-similar to running from Newcastle to the top of Slieve Commedagh.Zak summited Djouce in first place with a good gap over the second-placed runner to add another Irish cap to his list..prettyPhoto

title: ballinamallard supporters pulling out the stops for cup final
story: Trans-Atlantic trips, cancelled plane tickets, hopping back and forth across the Irish Sea. Just some of the trips and sacrices that are being made by Mallards supporters to ensure they are in Windosr Park for the biggest game in the clubrsquos history this Saturday.Kick off in the Irish Cup final is at .pm and the stands will be rocking with Mighty Duck supporters dreaming of the sweetest end to what has been an incredible journey.And speaking of journeys there are plenty being made this week. Former Ballinamallard manager Whitey Anderson boarded a plane in America, where he coaches soccer now, and has landed for the big day.ldquoIt is an occasion not to be missed for anyone involved in Ballinamallard, past or present. To get to a final is just fantastic and it is a two horse race now, he said.ldquoBest wishes to Harry and the back room team and all the players. I always liked managing at Windsor, we actually beat Linfield three times in four years there. To win a cup final would just be unbelievable and a great reward for everyone at the club for all the hard work that goes on.Another Ballinamallard fan who is flying across water is Stephen Armstrong. He hasnrsquot got as far to travel as Whitey as he lives in England but a four hour car journey has to be made to Newcastle before making his flight.A family wedding for his we meant that Stephen was earmarked for baby sitting duties. But a clash with the Mallardsrsquo big day meant some creative thinking was needed, and he found it in the shape of fellow Ballinamallard supporter Scott Williams.Scott lives in Newcastle and his we has kindly agreed to take charge of the two Amrstrong kids, along with her own two kids, for the weekend while her husband and Stephen head across the Irish Sea.ldquoIt is very good of her to let us go off gallivanting for the weekend, Stephen explained, before adding.ldquoWe are due to stay in Belast on Saturday night butballinamallard win it will be hard to resist a trip down the road.Someone better tell Mrs Williams she could have the kids for an extra night!Football writer and UEFA Communications consultant, Laure James, fell in love with the Mallards while covering them the season they were promoted to the Premiership back in . She posted a picture on twitter this week in her Ballinamallard top saying she was ldquobooking flights.Marshall Gillespie, another Fermanagh native who lives in England, and a renowned football statistician is also making his way home for the big day. For a lover of football history a chance to see the first Irish Cup final involving a Fermanagh team was something not to be missed with Marshall tweeting ldquoItrsquos going to be a quare day at Windsor!!Finally, one person very close to the squad has had to rebook flights for a wedding abroad. Mark McConkey, son of manager Harry, and a former player for Ballinamallard wasnrsquot going to miss the chance to see his dad manage a team in the Irish Cup final.ldquoIt is a once in a letime thing. Myself and dad have been through a few things in football and it is a family day for us all. So I just had to be there. Really looking forward to the day and there is a family bus organised for about  of us. We are looking forward it, Mark said before adding that they are still going to make that wedding before the bride is down the aisle.ldquoWe are getting collected at .am on Sunday morning and heading off then so we will be over in good time for the wedding.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. pots and plastic bottles have been cleaned off the beaches of Northern Ireland#s most famous coastline.Swimmers, jet skis and small boats all helped to reach bays at the bottom of steep clfs close to Unesco World Heritage Site the Giant’s Causeway.It was the National Trust’s third litter pick at sea in the area which is teeming with wildle from pods of dolphins to breeding seabirds, porpoises and even the occasional orca.Last August, volunteers lted more than two tonnes of rubbish in the second effort, following the first litter pick at sea in the area which took place in April.The initiative came after National Trust rangers noticed litter gathering on the remote beaches from clf top paths close to the Giant’s Causeway, while carrying out daily litter picks at the north Antrim attraction.Fiona Bryant, coastal officer for the National Trust in Northern Ireland, said they approached local outdoor activity providers for help.“With the mixture of dferent clubs – coasteering, surf and a e school – along with fishing vessels, it has been really helpful to get into each of the bays and make an impact by lting the litter there,” she said.However even with all that expertise, she said operating on the often treacherous section of coastline – including the point where in  the Spanish Armada’s Girona sank – demands a lot of preparation.Much of the litter is washed up to the shore by high tides and storms, and it can become lodged in rocks, making it hard to remove.“This point in the sea can be very stormy, and there is a lot of preparation goes into planning a day like this, from weather and tide conditions to the activity providers being available, our conservation rangers and all the staff,” she said.“Trying to get everything co-ordinated on the same day is quite an operation.“The volunteers have to swim to each bay to pick everything up and swim back so there is only so much you can do in one day.”Ms Bryant described the litter collected as a “real mixture”.New Gardeners’ Question Time chairwoman Kathy Clugston asked for equal payHolstein event of the year planned Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valDogs and their human companions are being invited to Dogs Trust Ballymena#s Family Fun Day on Saturday, May .Taking place at the Ballee Playing Fields in Ballymena from pm to pm, the event will offer plenty of fun and games for everyone including the ever-popular All-Day Fun Dog Show with classes including: Best Senior Dog, Cutest Puppy and Best Rescue Dog, so make sure your four-legged friends have their paws at the ready. Dogs and their human companions are being invited to Dogs Trust Ballymenas Family Fun Day at the Ballee Playing Fields on May .All proceeds from the day will go towards the continued care of residents at the Rehoming Centre, located outside the town at Teeshan.This year’s event will also mark the first ‘Doggy Olympics’ which will be held by Dogs Trust’s Dog School team in Northern Ireland. This will include an Olympic Dash course which has fun challenges for owners and their dogs to complete such as the loose lead egg and spoon race, with prizes up for grabs. Owners can also enter into a ‘Best trick of the day’ competition.Other activities available will include a Doggy Dash, a raffle, ious stalls and Dogs Trust Tombola. There will be Canine Carers on hand to offer rehoming advice, free microchipping and a Dogs Trust Reunion.Dogs Trust Ballymena Supporter Relations Officer Samuel Reid said: “Everything we do is for our rescue dogs and we hope you and your four-legged friends can join us on the day and show your support. We can promise you a really fun day out for all the family, with lots of activities available throughout the day.“It’s a fantastic opportunity to meet local dog lovers and raise pounds for the hounds in our care as the proceeds from the day help us to care for dogs like five-year-old Lurcher cross Banjo , currently staying at the Rehoming Centre.”Banjo is a sweet-natured dog who loves attention, as well as walks in quiet areas and will do anything for a tasty treat. He would prefer to be the only dog in the house and could live with older children.”Entry is £ per adult and children are free but encouraged to donate one tin of dog food. title: campaign to get penarth marina bridge open swings into action
story: In a letter to the Vale of Glamorgan Council, Penarth Marina and Haven Residents Association expressed concerns over the closure of Penarth Marina swing bridge.In May , the operators of the swing bridge linking the two halves of Penarth Marina closed the bridge. Three years on, operators Penarth Quays Marina and Vale owners have not agreed on a way to bring it back into operation. Gwynne Grfiths, chairman of the association, said: ldquoLoss of this amenity is particularly hard for those without access to a car who rely on public transport.ldquoThere is nothing mechanically wrong with the bridge. It was tested on February .ldquoThere appears to be disagreement between Penarth Quays and the Vale over the safety facilities needed to operate the bridge and minimise the impact on neighbouring houses and businesses.The Association is now campaigning for it to be reopened.A spokesperson for Penarth Quays Marina said: ldquoWe are obligated to operate the bridge based on an agreement made in , but the bridge was built to standards applicable in . Now, the bridge has several operational regulations like alarm levels ndash we canrsquot balance the high level of noise needed for a bridge and the low level needed for a residential area. This is the reality that the council have to consider and resolve.A Vale of Glamorgan Council spokesman said: ldquoThe swing bridge is maintained and operated by Quay Marinas, who manage the Penarth Quays Marina site.ldquoIt was closed due to a number of safety concerns, with upgrades needed before it can be reopened, including audible warnings.ldquoThe council is currently awaiting the outcome of a noise report following which our health and safety officers and those from Quay Marinas will discuss possible solutions which may enable the bridge to be reopened in the future. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ty hafan fundraiser features in national photography exhibition
story: Laura Grindey, who works for Sully-based T# Hafan, has been featured in lsquoBeing the Changersquo, a photography exhibition by BAFTA winning photographer Warren Orchard.Laura Grindey was among  voluntary sector members highlighted in the exhibition, put together by the Wales Council for Voluntary Action.Laura is part of the Supporter Care Team at T# Hafan, at the charityrsquos headquarters in Sully.She has been involved with T# Hafan for the past  years, starting as an  year old.The photo was snapped in T# Hafanrsquos upcycling project, in the handcrafted workshop, where volunteers and staff come to turn an unwanted item into a saleable pieces, with all profits going to the charity.WCVA commissioned Warren Orchard to showcase  charities and social enterprises to draw attention to the contribution of charity workers and volunteers across Wales.Chief executive Ruth Marks says: ldquoOur exhibition by the talented Warren Orchard really does reflect the humanity and good in all of us. title: new road linking m and a to end gridlock could impact families in pendoylan
story: Vale of Glamorgan Council has indicated a preferred route for the link road ndash which would link junction  of the M with the A south of Sycamore Cross.The council now prefers the road would go to the west of the village of Pendoylan ndash rather than to the east as previously considered.The scheme would also include a new railway station and park and ride near junction  of the M to link the motorway to Cardf Airport.The councilrsquos ruling body on April  agreed to further studies on the proposed scheme and to take the findings forward to a full business case.Councillor Jonathan Bird, cabinet member for regeneration and planning, told the meeting: ldquoWersquore becoming gridlockedcertainly in the western part of the Vale. Irsquom very keen to see this come further forward otherwise the Vale of Glamorgan is going to grind to a halt.Campaigners say villagers have been left in limbo by the plans because as many as nine families ndash % of the village ndash in Pendoylan could be forced to leave their homes as part of the plans.Campaigners say families are living daily with the anxiety and are unable to move on and sell their homes as the proposed new road is frightening potential buyers away.They say one elderly resident of Pendoylan, now living in a residential home, is unable to sell her house to pay for the care she needs as her property will be demolished to make way for the new roadthe councilrsquos plans proceed .And Vale Communities For Future Generations say residents inPendoylan and Peterston Super Ely could also be blighted by the air pollution and noise from HGVsthe road is built.The council says ldquono firm decision has been made to build a new road. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: Paul lsquoTin Tinrsquo Warren-Cox and Ian Norton, both from Penarth, have agreed to will do a ,ft skye for Prostate Cymru.ldquoDonrsquot ask me why Irsquom doing this crazy thing, said Mr Norton. ldquoFor a person who does not like heights, the more I think about it, the more I wonder what has happened to my rational thought processing ability. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: With an estimated one million people of all ages, from every corner of the UK and from all walks of le marching, the message was absolutely clear - that the people must be given a final say on this Brexit disaster.The atmosphere on the day was electric, and it was a real pleasure to join so many MPs, many thousands of people from the Labour and Co-operative families, and friends old and new at what was an incredible public statement.Meanwhile the petition that was launched calling for Article  to be revoked and for the UK to remain in the EU stood ndash at the time of writing this column ndash at . million signatures and climbing, with almost , signatures from this constituency .On Monday, the Prime Minister suffered another humiliating defeat in the House, when MPs voted to take control of the parliamentary timetable in an unprecedented move to try to find a majority for any Brexit option.The PM lost the vote by  votes to , with  of her own MPs voting against her, including three ministers.She has lost complete control of her party, her cabinet and of the Brexit process.Parliament has fought back - and now MPs must take responsibility for the process because the government is not doing its job.As I write this, we are awaiting a series of indicative votes on Wednesday to find out what kind of Brexit has most support among MPs ndash with potential options including a "softer Brexit", a customs union with the EU and another referendum.The aim of this is to test the will of Parliament to see what,anything, commands a majority.It really is astonishing that we have come to this ndash and yet Theresa May has already said there is no guarantee that she will abide by the wishes of the House.Away from Brexit, my Home Affairs Committee colleagues and I held an evidence session as part our inquiry into serious violence.We heard from, among others, Met Police Commissioner Cressida Dick, about the effectiveness of the Government and police services activities to counter the recent increase in violent crime, and the challenges facing police in this time of cutbacks. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: Hospice manager Sarah Lloyd-Davies with Keeping Faith actress Suzanne Packer, Maltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtrie Curie Divisionalltspan classtruncate-full-screengt General Manager Andrew Wilson-Mouasher and Karen and Jonathan Hodge of the Hodge Foundation. Credit: Patrick Olnerlt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" New Marie Curie cafe opens to publicCardf South and Penarth AM and Health Minister Vaughan Gething with Karen and ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtJonathan Hodge. Credltspan classtruncate-full-screengtit: Patrick Olnerlt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" New Marie Curie cafe opens to publicDay therapy manager Sam Clements, clinical nurse specialist Alison Palmer, Nurseltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgt Manager CNS Donna Lltspan classtruncate-full-screengtee and lead nurse Carolyn Gent enjoy a cuppa. Credit: Paltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgttrick Olnerlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA TERMINAL illness charity is attempting to bust the myths of hospice, by opening its doors to the general public with a new cafeacute.The Marie Curie Cafeacute at the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth was officially opened by actress Suzanne Packer, who is soon to appear in series two of Keeping Faith.The Marie Curie Cafeacute, situated in the basement of the hospice, has opened its doors not only to staff, patients and families ndash but will also be open to members of the public, who may be walking past in the nearby Windsor Gardens, and fancy popping in for a coffee and a cake.The UKrsquos leading terminal illness charity provides round-the-clock expert care and support to people living with a terminal illness, and their families at the Bridgeman Road Hospice. Marie Curie also provides support to people in their own homes, and its Information and Support Line now also features clinical nurse specialists who are available for any clinical support needed.The work to create the new cafeacute has been funded by the Hodge Foundation, who also supported the refurbishment of the hospicersquos Day Therapy and Outpatients Unit in .At the opening, cakes from the hospicersquos catering team were showcased, with staff, volunteers and patients joining Suzanne and the Hodge Foundation to enjoy welsh cakes and tea and coffee.Further works at the hospice, funded by a Legacy gt from the estate of Mrs Seaward have included the installation of a Spa bathroom on both inpatient units.There has also been further maintenance work carried out alongside the bathroom and cafeacute works. The works have been unveiled in a year in which the hospice is due to celebrate its th year.Sarah Lloyd-Davies, hospice manager, said: ldquoWe are so grateful to the Hodge Foundation for once again supporting vital work to not only allow us to continue to provide expert end of le care and support to people living with a terminal illness, and their families, but also to help us expand our reach to the community in Penarth.ldquoWe want people to understand more about the work we do here, and are excited to open our cafeacute doors and encourage people to come in and have conversations with us about end of le care.ldquoThank you also to the estate of Mrs Seaward for allowing us to create two relaxing and calming Spa bathrooms for patients, which help elevate the service we can provide at the hospice.Volunteer Ian Spence, who has been volunteering on reception for  years, is now also spending some hours helping in the cafeacute.He said: ldquoIt makes me feel good about myself. I get to give something back to the community, or rather put something into it.ldquoThe hospice is such a warm place to come to and the staff are all fantastic at making everyone feel welcome.Suzanne, who has previously visited the hospice with brother and Olympian Colin Jackson, said: ldquoItrsquos been a pleasure to officially open the new Marie Curie Cafeacute at the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth.ldquoMeeting the staff, volunteers and families and hearing stories about the care provided here for people living with a terminal illness has been inspiring. I wish the hospice every luck with their new venture, and hope it will encourage more people to talk about end of le with their loved ones.The Marie Curie cafeacute is currently open from .am to pm Monday to Friday, with plans to expand hours with trained volunteers.If you would like to volunteer, contact the hospice on    or visit www.mariecurie.org.uk volunteering article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale council caves in to arrogant dog owners over proposals to keep off sport pitches
story: Vale of Glamorgan Council has said a blanket ban on sports pitches will not be included in a proposed public spaces protection orderaimed at stopping anti-social dog walkers.Dog walkers would face fines of poundthey do not pick up their petsrsquo faeces at sports pitches or other public spaces, and there would also be seasonal bans on some beaches.The sports pitch ban was dropped following public opposition as a petition signed by , people opposed the move.But a consultation answered by , people found per cent supported the banning of dogs from marked sports pitches.Councillor Kevin Mahoney told the councilrsquos Environment and Regeneration Scrutiny Committee on April  that a blanket ban of dogs from sports pitches was the authorityrsquos ldquoone chance to deal with the issue of fouling on sports pitches.He said the ldquosheer arrogance of people to think they should demand that their dogs can go on sports pitches is ldquoabsolutely disgraceful.He added: ldquoIrsquove heard people whining theyrsquove got nowhere to walk their dog, but thatrsquos strange because Irsquom a dog owner and I donrsquot have any problem with that.ldquoItrsquos impossible to clear the complete amount of faeces left by even those so-called responsible dog owners.ldquoThis authority has admitted year after year itrsquos physically incapable of policing dog fouling.The one chance you have of keeping faeces off sports pitches is having a blanket ban so that any dog on there, the owner can be prosecuted.ldquoWho on earth do they think they are  These members of the public who have been so indignant and insistent their dogs should be allowed to do this  And who on earth are the Vale cabinet to agree with them and back down in this way He said the cabinet are ldquocaving into a bunch of indignant dog owners who, quite frankly,they canrsquot find anywhere to walk their dog as I do, they shouldnrsquot own a dog.Seasonal bans of dogs from Penarth seafront and the Knap beach are also set to be removed but dog bans will still apply on a seasonal basis at Whitmore Bay, Dunraven Bay and Cwm Colhuw.Dogs would still be banned from all childrenrsquos play areas, ecological conservation areas and bowling greens in the Vale, and they would be required to be on leads all year round onthe promenade at Whitmore Bay and Penarth seafront and pier.RSPCA Cymru opposed the sports pitch ban but agreed it should be an offence for dog owners not to clean up after their pets.Council leader John Thomas has previously said the council has taken peoplersquos views into account and has achieved a ldquobalanced position.Cllr Lis Burnett told the committee that dog owners had felt victimised by the proposals.ldquoItrsquos been so painful getting here, she said. ldquoIt was so painful for many members of the public who felt they were earmarked for derision as dog owners or dog walkers.ldquoWe need to learn from this exercise and understand that consultation is not engagement. So many people say lsquowhy wonrsquot the council talk to us "Cllr Steffan William askedsports pitches could be ldquofenced off to prevent dogs walking on them, but the councilrsquos operational manager Colin Smith said this ldquocould be quite costly for the council.At the start of the meeting, Mr Smith said: ldquoWe know the majority of dog owners are responsible and we donrsquot want to limit them from the green spaces the Vale has to offer.There were also calls for more dog waste bins throughout the Vale at the meeting.Councillors heard there have been just six prosecutions for dog fouling in the Vale of Glamorgan in the past year.Cardf councilrsquos PSPO against dog fouling will see dog owners fined poundtheyrsquore found without bags or the means of picking up after their pets.But Mr Smith said: ldquoThe legal team were concerned it wouldnrsquot be lawful. In the law it doesnrsquot state what you have to use to pick up the dog fouling. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: Last Wednesday, MPs had the opportunity to participate in indicative votes on ious Brexit-related motions.This unusual step came after an amendment was passed securing parliamentary time for debate and a series of votes on Brexit scenarios, to see which,any, might command a majority in the House of Commons.Following this, on Friday the Prime Minister brought her botched deal back to the house again, after what can only be described as political lsquotrickery of the highest orderrsquo.But yet again she was defeated, this time by  votes.This was another huge defeat despite increasingly desperate efforts by the Government to try and cajole people in the last few hours before the vote.I am not prepared to support a blindfold Brexit - so I voted NO. Surely it should be three strikes and out for this deal now And so on Monday, further indicative votes were held as MPs once again took control of parliamentary business ndash despite attempts by the government to shut down our debate before it started.Supporting the move to hold these further indicative votes on Monday, I said: ldquoI think Parliament made remarkable progress the other day in a few hours, compared with the Government, who have had two years to sort this out."It is important that we not only have the opportunity to make further progress tonight, but,necessary, a small amount of time on Wednesday to get to where we need to be, so that Parliament can take control and we can move forward together as a House.And so on Monday evening, there was a hugely signicant result placing a Peoplersquos Vote as the top option for resolving the impasse, with a Customs Union only narrowly missing out as well.I voted the same way as I did last week ndash for a Customs Union for a Peoplersquos Vote, and to revoke Article we face a No Deal Brexit.Itrsquos time for the PM to compromise for the good of the country.We all need to work together to find a solution.We need a credible Brexit option to be put to a public vote in a final say, with the option on the ballot paper to Remain, in order to find a way through this crisis. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: view from the senedd vaughan gething
story: That date has come and gone.Instead we now face the real possibility of crashing out of the EU without a deal on Friday April .We are still no closer to determining what our relationship with Europe will look like than we were two years ago.Understandably, I have been contacted by a number of constituents who look at the shambles in Westminster and just want to know what is going on.Since my last update Parliament has twice rejected Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal by large majorities.MPs have taken control of business in Westminster and the UK Government is openly fighting with itself.On Monday MPs debated for the second time alternative visions for Brexit.The proposals to stay in the Customs Union and for a confirmatory public vote had the greatest support ndash and more support than Theresa Mayrsquos deal ndash but nothing had a majority.The choice of the UK Government to run down the clock have made the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal more likely.Theresa Mayrsquos deal is plainly not going through Parliament but no deal is even more unpalatable.A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit would be bad for Wales and bad for jobs here in Cardf South and Penarth.Manufacturers, trade unions and a wide range of businesses have told us that jobs and livelihoods are at risk.We have already seen that the threat of Brexit is a real factor in jobs that have already left the UK.An industry study has warned that should we leave with no deal it could result in a loss of , jobs, with , of these jobs in Wales.It would cost the jobs of families that I represent.In my government role I have met with health and social care leaders to discuss the impact of a no deal Brexit and to plan our response.We want to ensure an uninterrupted supply of medication and secure the rights of EU nationals working within Wales.Last week I announced the acquisition of a warehouse in south Wales to provide additional storage health and care equipment to ensure there is a continuity of supply for Wales.The Welsh Government has also set up a Business Wales portal to help businesses in Wales prepare for Brexit.It has also created a poundmillion fund to help businesses prepare for the challenges of Brexit.I would urge businesses in Cardf South and Penarth to visit the Business Wales portal and find out about the support that is available.However all of our preparations cannot remove the risk of disruption.A no deal would be highly damaging for our health and care system and the people who rely upon it.I cannot overstate how much time energy and effort has been soaked up in preparing for a No Deal instead of improving our health and care system.No Deal is not a consequence free choice.It is a scandalous waste of our resources and the commitment of our staff.Politicians who bravely talk about a managed No Deal have not had to confront the realities of preparing for it or the scale of waste and damage it would cause.The most troubling aspect of Brexit has been that the isions within the UK are growing.For all my disappointment, Parliament is not enemy territory, as Nigel Farage claimed. That anger and stoking of ision is dangerous and irresponsible.At that same rally we saw a leader of the far right who is a convicted violent racist criminal being applauded on stage.That should not make any us proud regardless of how we voted.The biggest threat to the union of the UK comes from a No Deal.It would not only destabilise politics in Northern Ireland but it would almost certainly guarantee another Scottish independence referendum.More turmoil that would not turn back the tide of austerity or add a single extra penny into our schools, the NHS or any other public service that we rely upon.I do not believe a ided UK Parliament can make a choice for the next generation of our ided countries.I was proud to sponsor two coaches and march alongside more than a million members of the public, including many people from Cardf South and Penarth calling for a Peoplersquos Vote.We need to go back to the people with a choice between a Brexit deal that Parliament can agree and our current deal within the EU.There is no simple choice to the isions that we face but I would as ever be interested to hear views from my constituents. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... That anger and stoking of ision is dangerous and irresponsible.At that same rally we saw a leader of the far right who is a convicted violent racist criminal being applauded on stage.That should not make any us proud regardless of how we voted.The biggest threat to the union of the UK comes from a No Deal.It would not only destabilise politics in Northern Ireland but it would almost certainly guarantee another Scottish independence referendum.More turmoil that would not turn back the tide of austerity or add a single extra penny into our schools, the NHS or any other public service that we rely upon.I do not believe a ided UK Parliament can make a choice for the next generation of our ided countries.I was proud to sponsor two coaches and march alongside more than a million members of the public, including many people from Cardf South and Penarth calling for a Peoplersquos Vote.We need to go back to the people with a choice between a Brexit deal that Parliament can agree and our current deal within the EU.There is no simple choice to the isions that we face but I would as ever be interested to hear views from my constituents. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: victoria primary pupils clean penarth beach after inspiring visit
story: As a part of their science topic of Habitats, Year Three pupils from Victoria Primary School, Penarth recently had a visit from the National Marine Aquarium.The aquarium held several fascinating workshops for the children to take part in.The aquarium made use of cutting-edge technology, including Virtual Reality headsets.Using the headsets, the children were able to lsquoersquo more than m down into the ldquoMidnight Zone.The Midnight Zone is one of the deepest, darkest areas of the ocean, and the children had the chance to see the predators and their prey in action.They also explored the food chains found in the seas and oceans of our world.They further examined the impact of plastic on these food chains and their habitats.Following these workshops, Year Three decided to undertake a beach clean on Penarth beach.Equipment was loaned by Keep Wales Tidy, the Welsh environmental charity.The youngsters did exceptionally well on their beach clean, collecting three full bags of rubbish in  minutes.They discussed dferent types of rubbish found, where it could have come from and its impact on the beach habitat and the ecosystem. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
